Title: Facilitation of recall by linguistic structure in nonsense strings
Authors with affiliations: O'Connell, D.C., St. Louis U
Abstract: Discusses research on the facilitation of recall through the introduction of linguistic structure (bound morphemes, functors, syntax) into nonsense strings. This effect is well-established, but delicate, being influenced by the wordlike character of the nonsense stems, string length, stage of learning, rate and mode of presentation and response mode. It is suggested that future research must be based more firmly on both psycholinguistic and verbal learning methodology. (43 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: linguistic structure in nonsense strings, facilitation of recall

Title: Peripheral physiological variables and emotion: The James-Lange theory revisited
Authors with affiliations: Fehr, F.S., U. Illinois, Children's Research Center; Stern, J.A.
Abstract: Considers that while there are a number of current reviews of the literature which emphasize the important relationships between CNS system variables and emotion, less attention has been given to the possible relevance of peripheral autonomic variables for a more comprehensive understanding of emotional behavior. Findings which are relevant to current concepts of the physiology of emotions are examined within the traditional and familiar framework of the James-Lange theory of emotion. This theory generated a number of hypotheses regarding peripheral autonomic functioning, and a great deal of research has accumulated relevant to them. Commonly reiterated and controversial aspects of the theory are reviewed in terms of current research findings of physiological functioning, studies involving the artificial induction of autonomic responses, differential patterns of physiological response, and feedback to the CNS autonomic activity. (106 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: peripheral autonomic functioning, emotional behavior, examination of James-Lange theory of emotion
Index Keywords: article; attention; autonomic nervous system; emotion; feedback system; gastrointestinal tract; human; peripheral nerve; stress; Attention; Autonomic Nervous System; Emotions; Feedback; Gastrointestinal System; Human; Peripheral Nerves; Stress

Title: Individual differences in figural aftereffects
Authors with affiliations: Over, R., U. Queensland, St. Lucia, Australia
Abstract: Discusses recent experiments which indicate that the magnitude of a figural aftereffect is dependent on decision processes in addition to stimulus variables. The influence of judgment time, expectation, and instructional criterion on figural aftereffect is examined. It is suggested that the lack of attention paid to these variables may be responsible for the discrepant findings that have been characteristic of research in the area. (32 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: expectation &; instructional criterion, figural aftereffect magnitude; judgment time &
Index Keywords: article; decision making; human; learning; reaction time; time; vision; Decision Making; Figural Aftereffect; Human; Reaction Time; Set (Psychology); Time Factors

Title: Sexual dimorphism and homosexual gender identity
Affiliations: Johns Hopkins Hosp., Baltimore, Md, United States
Authors with affiliations: Money, J., Johns Hopkins Hosp., Baltimore, Md, United States
Abstract: Proposes that the classification of homosexuality as hereditary or constitutional vs. acquired is outmoded. It is suggested that the differentiation should be between chronic, obligative, or essential vs. transient, facultative, or optional. Cytogenetics and statistical genetics do not elucidate etiology, but new research on fetal hormonal differentiation of sexual morphology, and especially of sexually dimorphic hypothalamic differentiation offers promising leads. The sum total of the sex-differential effects of assignment and rearing on gender identity differentiation is known, through observations of hermaphrodites, to be profound. Postpubertally, homosexuality does not correlate with hormonal measures presently available or with assessments of neuroperceptual sex differences in erotic arousal. It is concluded that sexual dimorphism of brain functioning in gender identity is the end product of sequential events of critical periods, with pre- and postnatal effects interacting, and the end product being extremely durable. (76 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: fetal hormonal differentiation of sexual morphology &; sexual dimorphic hypothalamic differentiation, homosexuality
Index Keywords: sex hormone; article; brain; cytogenetics; female; genetics; hermaphroditism; homosexuality; human; identity; male; physiology; sex chromosome; sex differentiation disorder; Brain; Cytogenetics; Female; Genetics; Hermaphroditism; Homosexuality; Human; Identification (Psychology); Male; Sex Chromosomes; Sex Differentiation Disorders; Sex Hormones; Statistics
Correspondence Address: Money, J.; Johns Hopkins Hosp., Baltimore, Md, United States

Title: Human discrimination learning: The subset-sampling assumption
Affiliations: State U. New York, Stony Brook
Authors with affiliations: Levine, M., State U. New York, Stony Brook
Abstract: Discusses the common assumption in hypothesis models of discrimination learning that an S samples a single hypothesis and that this hypothesis dictates his response. An alternative assumption, termed subset-sampling, is that an S samples several hypotheses at a time. The S may then either take 1, a working hypothesis, as the basis for his response, or make the response consistent with the majority of the hypotheses in his subset. Data that favor the subset-sampling assumption are: (a) methods for measuring the size of the hypothesis universe show that the S is evaluating and correctly rejecting several hypotheses per trial; (b) during the criterion run of correct responses, latencies decrease until the S holds only the correct hypothesis. After this point the latencies are constant; (c) in experiments with 2 relevant and redundant cues, Ss occasionally learn both solutions; and (d) some stimulus sequences produce a preponderance of response to 1 side in excess of that predicted by the single-hypothesis assumption. (19 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sampling hypothesis which dictates responses, discrimination learning
Index Keywords: article; discrimination learning; human; memory; problem solving; reaction time; Discrimination Learning; Human; Memory; Problem Solving; Reaction Time
Correspondence Address: Levine, M.; State U. New York, Stony Brook

Title: Aging, brain damage, and psychomotor slowing
Authors with affiliations: Hicks, L.H., Howard U; Birren, J.E.
Abstract: Reviews research on psychomotor slowing in aged and brain-damaged Ss and attempts to identify brain mechanisms related to this slowing. Behavioral, neuroanatomical, and neurophysiological evidence indicate that the basal ganglia with their complex neural connections are importantly involved in the speed of initiating and executing movements. It is suggested that damage or dysfunction of the basal ganglia may be a basis for the psychomotor slowness observed in human and animal Ss. (174 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: brain-damaged Ss; dysfunction of basal ganglia, psychomotor slowing, aged &

Title: Equivalence of information in concept identification
Affiliations: National Inst. of Health, Gerontology Research Center, Baltimore, Md, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arenberg, D., National Inst. of Health, Gerontology Research Center, Baltimore, Md, United States
Abstract: Describes a method which provides equivalent amounts of information for logically equivalent selections in concept identification when Ss select instances. Equivalence is maintained between comparable conjunctive and disjunctive problems as well as within a particular problem type. This equivalence-of-information method permits amount of information gained to be used to measure performance for each selection. The nonequivalence of available information which usually results when solutions are fixed and when Ss select instances is avoided by this method. Data from an experiment in which the equivalence-of-information method is used suggest that amount of initial information gain is a variable that merits investigation and indicate that pooling results of concept problems with high and low initial information may obscure important differences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: concept identification, equivalence of information method
Correspondence Address: Arenberg, D.; National Inst. of Health, , Baltimore, Md, United States

Title: Defining shape for perceptual element-position curves
Authors with affiliations: Harcum, E.R., Coll. of William and Mary
Abstract: Attempts to resolve the controversy between M. Glanzer (see record 1968-13029-001) and E. R. Harcum (see record 1968-13030-001) about whether the perceptual serial-position curve should be described in absolute or relative terms, particularly with reference to the degree of asymmetry. 4 measures of asymmetry are discussed: (a) absolute differences in errors between elements on the left vs. right of center; (b) left-right differences weighted according to totals of errors; (c) relative frequencies of Ss showing superior perception for a given 1/2 of the pattern; and (d) rank order of elements according to relative accuracy. The superiority of the conception in relative terms is established primarily through interpretation of empirical results. It is concluded that a fine-grained analysis of individual differences in perceptual strategy, using all available measures for shape of error distributions, should be applied to the theoretical issues in this area. (53 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: E. Harcum; perceptual element-position curve, asymmetry measurement definitions, contribution to M. Glanzer &
Correspondence Address: Harcum, E.R.; Coll. of William and Mary

Title: Note on how to choose a visual noise mask
Authors with affiliations: Haber, R.N., U. Rochester
Abstract: Presents a methodological plea to investigators of visual masking: Investigators should think carefully about the purposes for which they use a mask, so that they can maximize the selection of an appropriate one and use it in an appropriate design. Several specific rules are offered: (a) to measure the process-stopping potential of a mask, a mask should be chosen that has some chance to interfere with or prevent processing when superimposed over the target; (b) to control the masking effects of poststimulus indicators, adjacency should be avoided as much as possible, or perhaps a different sensory system should be used, and control and base-line data should be collected; and (c) to study the perceptual effects of masking, the S should be asked what he sees, in addition to merely demanding a recognition response or a guess. Other such rules are potentially available, though not elaborated in this brief note. Without care in the selection of masks, and the experimental designs in which they are presented, however, the analysis of perceptual masking effects is far more difficult. (24 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: visual noise mask, selection criteria in experimentation
Index Keywords: article; cognition; human; vision; Cognitive Dissonance; Human; Visual Perception

Title: Bargaining and reciprocity
Authors with affiliations: Nemeth, C., U. Chicago
Abstract: Numerous studies in the area of bargaining have attempted to raise the usual low level of cooperation between players by programing 1 person's play as cooperative. Implicit in the design of such studies is a notion of reciprocity, i.e., that Ss will feel obligated to return benefits. The failure of such attempts to raise the level of cooperation suggests an apparent contradiction between the norm of reciprocity, which is postulated as a universal norm, and findings of the bargaining studies which show little or no reciprocity. An attempt is made to resolve such a contradiction by addressing several variables intrinsic to the particular paradigm used in the bargaining studies. A selective review of the 2 literatures suggests that such variables intrinsic to the paradigms all operate in such a way as to inhibit a norm of reciprocity, and indeed help giving in general. It is concluded that the lack of reciprocity typically found in bargaining games is not because reciprocity is inoperative, but is rather due to the paradigms normally employed for the study of cooperation and competition. (38 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: bargaining &; competition paradigms; reciprocity experimentation, cooperation &

Title: Nonparametric index of response bias for use in detection and recognition experiments
Affiliations: Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Washington, D.C, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hodos, W., Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Washington, D.C, United States
Abstract: Describes a simple graphical method for the determination of response bias or criterion in detection and recognition experiments. The method is based only on the geometry of the unit square and makes no assumptions about the statistical properties of sensory events associated with the occurrence of signal and nonsignal conditions. Examples of some applications of this technique are presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: detection &; recognition experimentation, graphical method measurement of response bias
Correspondence Address: Hodos, W.; Walter Reed Army Medical Center, Washington, D.C, United States

Title: On looking at an elephant: An evaluation of cross-cultural research related to organizations
Authors with affiliations: Roberts, K.H., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Categorizes the literature into 26 substantive areas and further classifies it on the bases of whether entries offer micro- or macro-data, and the vantage point from which research questions are asked. Thus, findings concerned with the characteristics of individuals in organizations, organizational subunits, organizational totalities, and organizational interactions are considered. The available work is considered in terms of 3 questions: (a) from this research, do we know anything new; (b) are investigations guided by theoretical principles that suggest relevant questions; and (c) are the methodological approaches useful? The problem of defining culture is discussed, and some of the variables that should be looked at in future work are suggested. A few substantive and methodological approaches that might be helpful are mentioned. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: organizational behavior, evaluation of cross-cultural research
Correspondence Address: Roberts, K.H.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Covert oral behavior during the silent performance of language tasks
Authors with affiliations: McGuigan, F.J., Hollins Coll
Abstract: Summarizes and evaluates research in which covert oral responses were recorded. In early studies mechanical sensing devices were used while later research has exclusively employed EMG. 3 major criteria were used in evaluating research on the silent performance of language ("thinking") tasks, leading to the following conclusions: (a) covert oral behavior significantly increases over base line; (b) increased covert oral behavior is accompanied by increased respiration rate and increased amplitude of EMGs in the preferred (writing) arm, but appears to be relatively independent of other nonoral behavior; and (c) covert oral behavior does not appear to typically increase during the performance of nonlanguage tasks. A set of 5 directly relevant findings leads to the conclusion that covert oral behavior during the silent performance of language tasks serves a language function; mediational theories, built on overt behavior, help to suggest more precisely that the covert oral response facilitates the reception of external language stimuli and the internal processing of that information. Physiological considerations indicate complex and rapid feedback loops between speech regions of the brain and the speech musculature. These loops may function in the process of internal communication. (53 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: covert oral behavior during silent performance of language tasks, internal communication &; information processing

Title: Is there a deprivation-satiation function for social approval?
Authors with affiliations: Eisenberger, R., U. California, Riverside, United States
Abstract: Examines the replicability and interpretation of J. L. Gewirtz and D. M. Baer's findings that the reinforcement efficacy of social approval increases with prior deprivation of approval and decreases with prior satiation of approval. These results were successfully replicated in an impressive number of studies using choice measures of instrumental performance. While studies employing rate or duration measures have yielded weak and inconsistent effects, methodological deficiencies in these studies make their interpretation highly equivocal. Experimental evidence suggests that changes in approval-contingent performance resulting from deprivation-satiation operations are not attributable simply to changes in general sensory deprivation, general drive level, or cue properties of approval comments. Therefore, the view that the withholding and presentation of approval alter the motivation for obtaining approval is supported. (57 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: D. Baer; reinforcement value of social approval, prior deprivation of approval vs. prior satiation of approval, contribution to J. Gewirtz &
Correspondence Address: Eisenberger, R.; U. California, Riverside, United States

Title: Extinction of avoidance responding through response prevention (flooding)
Authors with affiliations: Baum, M., Bishop's U., Lennoxville, Que., Canada
Abstract: Discusses the resistance to extinction of avoidance responding, and describes a treatment for hastening extinction. The treatment, known as response prevention (flooding), consists of thwarting the avoidance response while forcing the S to remain in the situation which it fears. Behavior therapy analogues to response prevention are reviewed, and the various factors which determine the efficacy of response prevention with animals are described. Pharmacological and behavioral techniques for enhancing the effectiveness of response prevention are noted. 3 theories (2-process theory, competing response theory, and a relaxation analysis), which attempt to explain why and how response prevention works, are discussed, and it is concluded that no 1 theory provides an adequate account of all the results obtained. (49 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: competing response &; extinction of avoidance responding by response prevention, 2-process &; relaxation analysis theories, behavior therapy analogues
Index Keywords: animal; article; aversion therapy; avoidance behavior; behavior therapy; electric shock; fear; human; leisure; rat; reinforcement; Animal; Aversive Therapy; Avoidance Learning; Behavior Therapy; Electroshock; Extinction (Psychology); Fear; Human; Rats; Relaxation
Correspondence Address: Baum, M.; Bishop's U., Lennoxville, Que., Canada

Authors: Graen G., Alvares K., Orris J.B., Martella J.A.
Title: Contingency model of leadership effectiveness: Antecedent and evidential results
Authors with affiliations: Graen, G., U. Illinois; Alvares, K.; Orris, J.B.; Martella, J.A.
Abstract: Analyzes the contingency model of leadership effectiveness and its supporting research from strategical and procedural perspectives. Numerous potential and realized problems are discussed. It is concluded that although the antecedent probability based upon previously published reports appeared to be greater than 0, the evidential probability based upon the evidence reviewed herein approaches 0. Thus, the resulting inverse probability casts grave doubt on the plausibility of the contingency model. (29 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: contingency model of leadership effectiveness, analysis
Index Keywords: adult; article; group psychology; human; leadership; male; model; problem solving; social dominance; Adult; Group Processes; Human; Leadership; Male; Models, Psychological; Problem Solving; Social Dominance

Title: Differential reinforcement of low rates: A selective critique
Authors with affiliations: Kramer, T.J., St. Louis U; Rilling, M.
Abstract: Reviews the literature relevant to the DRL with respect to measurement of the behavior, bursts of responding, sequential dependencies, extinction and reconditioning, comparative aspects, punishment, reinforcement of 2 interresponse times, amount of deprivation and reinforcement, behavioral contrast, stimulus generalization, and response generalization. Results suggest that: (a) bursts of responding could be due to a lack of stimulus feedback, (b) similar interresponse times tend to follow each other, (c) the development of mediating behavior is correlated with responding which is more appropriate to the schedule contingencies, and (d) Ss "preferred" short interresponse times. The shape of the stimulus generalization gradients after training on a DRL schedule is either peaked, flat, or inverted depending on the schedule value and prior training. Studies loosely concerned with response generalization suggest that responding under this schedule may be qualitatively different from responding under a variable-interval schedule. Experimental approaches for investigating the possible inhibitory and/or aversive properties of differential reinforcement are indicated. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: DRL, review of literature

Title: Path analysis: Psychological examples
Affiliations: Educational Testing Service, Developmental Research Div., Princeton, N.J, United States
Authors with affiliations: Werts, C.E., Educational Testing Service, Developmental Research Div., Princeton, N.J, United States; Linn, R.L.
Abstract: Demonstrates the usefulness of path analysis by applying it to a set of kindred problems: (a) the correlation of true scores over time, allowing specified measurement errors to be correlated; (b) the "bouncing beta" in stepwise regression analysis; (c) the specification of the number and interrelationships of latent variables in a set of data; (d) adjustments for covariate unreliability in the analysis of covariance; and (e) the analysis of multitrait-multimethod matrices. (16 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: path analysis, applications to traditional psychological problems of statistical analysis
Correspondence Address: Werts, C.E.; Educational Testing Service, , Princeton, N.J, United States

Title: Attitude measurement and the linear model
Authors with affiliations: Ramsay, J.O., McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada; Case, B.
Abstract: A model proposed by M. Fishbein and L. R. Tucker for attitude is identical to the linear model in statistical inference. In this model, the evaluative reaction to a stimulus is a consequence of summing the product of the evaluative reaction to a relevant property and the stimulus scale value on that property across all relevant properties. If the scale values of the stimuli on the relevant properties are known, then a multiple regression of the stimulus evaluations on the property scale values will provide estimates of the evaluative reactions to the properties. An experiment is described in which 26 undergraduates' attitudes toward countries are analyzed using the model. It is concluded that the model fits the data well and allows several interesting statements to be made about the cognitive and evaluative components of these attitudes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: attitude measurement model, statistical inference linear model similarity enabling measurement of cognitive &; evaluative components
Correspondence Address: Ramsay, J.O.; McGill U., Montreal, Que., Canada

Title: Some comments on "Techniques for estimating the source and direction of influence in panel data"
Authors with affiliations: Howard, K.I., Northwestern U; Krause, M.S.
Abstract: Further techniques for the determination and description of causal influence in nonexperimental data were recently introduced by A. H. Yee and N. L. Gage (see record 1968-14714-001). These methods, however, do not rest on an adequate formulation of causal logic. Some elements of such a formulation are presented, and their application to the procedures outlined by Yee and Gage are indicated. Attention is given to the selection of rival hypotheses, the assumptions underlying the several analytic techniques, and the function of plausibility and prior substantive commitment in the analysis of nonexperimental research. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: analysis; N. Gage's model of causal influence &; nonexperimental research data, procedural applications of A. Yee &

Title: Toward an analysis of subjective phrase structure
Authors with affiliations: Martin, E., U. Michigan, Human Performance Center
Abstract: A method for ascertaining the subjective organization of English sentences is presented, discussed, and experimentally applied. It is argued that the a priori phrase markers that psycholinguists have been using in theory and research are in need of empirical determination, and that subjective phrasing departs from prescriptive phrasing. It is also shown that relative constituent compactness can be determined empirically. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: adherence to prescriptive phrasing; subjective phrase structure analysis, psycholinguistic marking &

Title: Linear regression, structural relations, and measurement error
Authors with affiliations: Isaac, P.D., Ohio State U
Abstract: Distinguishes between situations to which linear regression analysis is applicable and situations which involve linear structural relations. Although both situations involve estimates of linear parameters, the parameters serve a different purpose in the 2 situations, and, consequently, their estimates in general will differ. The assumptions and predictive nature of regression are reviewed and contrasted with the assumptions and nature of linear structural relations. In the structural relation, there is no question about 2 regression lines; only 1 line is of interest. The implications of measurement errors for the 2 situations are pointed out. An example is given in which linear regression analysis was used inappropriately, and in which the analysis for a linear structural relation would have been appropriate. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: linear regression analysis vs. linear structural relations, implications of measurement errors

Title: Some properties of ipsative, normative, and forced-choice normative measures
Authors with affiliations: Hicks, L.E.
Abstract: Evaluates and summarizes the relevant literature describing mathematical and empirical properties of ipsative and nonipsative measures. The need for a simple procedure for quantifying the "degree of ipsativity" in measuring instruments is indicated. It is concluded that although nonipsative (normative or forced-choice normative) measuring instruments can be highly effective in most assessment situations, purely ipsative instruments possess such extensive psychometric limitations that use of such instruments is not recommended. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: empirical properties of ipsative vs. normative vs. forced-choice normative measurement; mathematical &

Title: Analytical approach to the correlation between related pairs of subjects on psychological tests
Authors with affiliations: Humphreys, L.G., U. Illinois
Abstract: It has been shown that the resemblance coefficient between related pairs, e.g., twins, on a composite measure is a function of 3 kinds of correlations involving the component measures: within-person (homogeneity), cross-pair-same-measures, and cross-pair-different-measures correlations. Present data suggest that there is substantial variation among these from 1 related group to another. As a result, the size of the resemblance coefficient is an arbitrary function of the components used by the test constructer. The research person need not accept current tests as given, but instead can control the weights assigned to components in accordance with a rational plan of analysis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: resemblance coefficient between related pairs on psychological tests

Title: Models for affiliative and conformity behavior
Affiliations: U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mehrabian, A., U. California, Los Angeles, United States; Ksionzky, S.
Abstract: Reviews and integrates findings and measures available in the area of affiliation and the related field of conformity. Affiliative characteristics are represented in terms of a 2-dimensional scheme, based on generalized expectation of the positively and negatively reinforcing quality of interpersonal relationships. Treating each of these dimensions dichotomously, 4 categories of affiliator are obtained. These 4 categories are related to existing measures of affiliative tendency. Implications of available research are used to elaborate a model in which affiliative behavior, the dependent variable, is a function of affiliative characteristics, and attributes of the target of affiliation or the situation in which affiliation occurs. Conformity behavior, in a related model, is then expressed as a function of affiliative characteristics and target attributes. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: affiliation &; conformity, review
Correspondence Address: Mehrabian, A.; U. California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Simple compact portable test of normality: Geary's test revisited
Authors with affiliations: D'Agostino, R.B., Boston U
Abstract: R. C. Geary's test of normality, based solely on the ratio of the sample mean deviation to the sample standard deviation is suggested to the research psychologist. This test is computationally easy and has good sensitivity to nonnormality. To further facilitate the test and to broaden its applicability a normal approximation to the test is given and investigated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Geary's test of normality

Title: Audiotape and videotape self-confrontation in psychotherapy
Affiliations: Virginia Commonwealth U., Richmond, Va, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bailey, K.G., Virginia Commonwealth U., Richmond, Va, United States; Sowder, W.T.
Abstract: Reviews the research literature on self-confrontation in psychotherapy with emphasis on audio- and videotape playback techniques. Playback is lauded by most writers and numerous benefits are ascribed, but experimental support is lacking. The few controlled studies extant are criticized, and suggestions are offered for designing and interpreting future experiments in the area. Self-confrontation is presented as a rapidly developing approach which deserves a thorough investigation of its practical and heuristic possibilities. (64 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: self-confrontation in psychotherapy, audio- &; videotape playback
Index Keywords: article; human; psychotherapy; self concept; tape recorder; television; Human; Psychotherapy; Self Concept; Tape Recording; Television
Correspondence Address: Bailey, K.G.; Virginia Commonwealth U., Richmond, Va, United States

Title: Characteristic sequential dependencies in multiple-choice situations
Authors with affiliations: Rabinowitz, F.M., U. Washington
Abstract: Briefly reviews the literature relevant to the response-response sequential dependencies exhibited by humans in multiple-choice situations (k > 2). It is concluded that human behavior is characterized by 3 types of sequential dependencies that appear in a wide variety of experimental situations. These include the tendency to: (a) not repeat responses, (b) respond to adjacent loci on successive trials (respond in a series), and (c) use all k possible responses on k successive trials. It is noted that the tendency to respond in a series decreases as a function of increasing age and increasing interresponse interval, while the tendency not to repeat responses decreases as a function of increasing interresponse interval. It is also concluded that characteristic sequential dependencies are not usually the result of either attempts to optimize stimulus input or minimize reactive inhibition. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: response-response sequential dependencies in multiple-choice situations

Title: Memory and the theory of signal detection
Authors with affiliations: Lockhart, R.S., U. Toronto, Ont., Canada; Murdock, B.B.
Abstract: Discusses the use of signal detection theory as a model of the decision process in memory in terms of the problems of identification and testing. Identification refers to the matching of elements of the formal theory with constructs constituting a theory of memory. A number of issues are raised concerning the identification of the sensory continuum, the decision axis, and the distinction between signal and noise. The use of detection theory is not a theoretically neutral method of dealing with response bias; the validity of its use and the manner of its application depend heavily on certain assumptions about the memory system. The form of the operating characteristic can be used to test a number of these assumptions but such tests are relatively insensitive. The use of detection theory in the analysis of cued-recall data poses additional problems and is meaningful in the context of some, but not all, theories of recall. (26 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory &; theory of signal detection
Correspondence Address: Lockhart, R.S.; U. Toronto, Ont., Canada

Title: Signal detection theory and human memory
Authors with affiliations: Banks, W.P., Pomona Coll
Abstract: Critically reviews 4 categories of applications of signal detection theory (SDT) in the study of memorial processes: (a) to scale memory strength, (b) in criterial interpretations of data that seem to indicate forgetting, (c) to determine the form of trace storage and to settle the question of all-or-none learning, and (d) extensions of SDT to scale memory-based discriminability in finer analyses of retention. The techniques that SDT offers the student of memory are explained, their limitations and past misapplications are discussed, their advantages in various situations are enumerated, and future applications are suggested. (47 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: memory &; signal detection theory, review

Title: How we should measure "change": Or should we?
Authors with affiliations: Cronbach, L.J., Stanford U., School of Education; Furby, L.
Abstract: Examines procedures previously recommended by various authors for the estimation of "change" scores, "residual," or "basefree" measures of change, and other kinds of difference scores. A procedure proposed by F. M. Lord is extended to obtain more precise estimates, and an alternative to the L. R. Tucker, F. Damarin, and S. A. Messick (see 41:3) procedure is offered. A consideration of the purposes for which change measures have been sought in the past leads to a series of recommended procedures which solve research and personnel-decision problems without estimation of change scores for individuals. (22 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: measurement of change in psychometrics, review of statistical methods

Title: Measurement of clustering in free recall
Authors with affiliations: Dalrymple-Alford, E.C., American U., Beirut, Lebanon
Abstract: Presents formulas likely to be useful in measuring clustering in free recall. The inadequacy of the "ratio of repetition" index is pointed out and a new index proposed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: clustering in free recall, measurement formulas
Correspondence Address: Dalrymple-Alford, E.C.; American U., Beirut, Lebanon

Title: Attempts to predict suicidal risk using psychological tests
Affiliations: Suicide-Prevention and Crisis Service, Inc., Buffalo, N.Y, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lester, D., Suicide-Prevention and Crisis Service, Inc., Buffalo, N.Y, United States
Abstract: Reviews and criticizes research investigating the use of psychological tests in identifying and predicting suicidal behavior. Of the standard psychological tests, only the Rorschach and the MMPI have potential as predictors of suicidal behavior but, as yet, this potential is unrealized. Of the scales devised for the specific purpose of predicting suicidal behavior, the Devries suicide inventory and scales based on admissions data appear to be useful predictors. A distinction is made between test-oriented research and task-oriented research in this area, and the superiority of task-oriented research is noted. The most fruitful orientation for research is toward tests devised specifically to identify and predict suicidal risk and away from the use of general tests of personality. (71 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: suicidal behavior prediction, existing personality measurement techniques &; test- vs. task-oriented research
Index Keywords: article; human; psychologic test; suicide; Human; Psychological Tests; Suicide
Correspondence Address: Lester, D.; Suicide-Prevention and Crisis Service, Inc., Buffalo, N.Y, United States

Title: Sensory capacities of the chimpanzee: A review
Authors with affiliations: Prestrude, A.M., Virginia Polytechnic Inst
Abstract: Summarizes and evaluates available information about the chimpanzee's sensory abilities. Investigation of the chimpanzee's sensory processes has been limited mainly to vision and audition. Where reliable information is available, the sensory systems of the chimpanzee and human are highly similar in structure and function. Chimpanzees, like humans, are trichromats and each has similar visual acuity. Perceptual phenomena, i.e., color and brightness contrast and movement, appear to be similar functions. Absolute auditory thresholds are similar for chimpanzees and humans, but the chimpanzee can apparently detect higher frequencies than the human. Only qualitative observations are available on the functions of the chimpanzee in the other sensory modalities so that chimpanzee-human comparisons in these modalities are largely conjecture. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sensory processes, chimpanzee, review
Index Keywords: animal; animal behavior; article; comparative anatomy; hearing; human; physiology; Pongidae; sensation; species difference; vision; Anatomy, Comparative; Animal; Behavior, Animal; Hearing; Human; Physiology, Comparative; Pongidae; Sensation; Species Specificity; Vision

Title: A model for partitioning judgment error in psychophysics
Affiliations: Pacific State Hosp., Socio-Behavioral Lab., Pomona, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Eyman, R.K., Pacific State Hosp., Socio-Behavioral Lab., Pomona, CA, United States; Kim, P.J.
Abstract: Presents a model for examining the "errors" made in psychophysical judgments in the context of analysis of variance. Based on data from an experiment employing 16 graduate students, the structural relationship between the stimuli and response patterns appears to be a function of the placement of the standard stimuli and the order of magnitude of the numerical values which Ss are asked to use at the standard stimulus levels. An argument is made for the partitioning of judgment error as a useful method for greater understanding and isolation of the effects of many of the experimental factors known to affect psychophysical judgments. (23 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: analysis of variance, model; judgment error partitioning in psychophysics, response matrix &
Index Keywords: analysis of variance; article; decision making; model; psychophysics; Analysis of Variance; Judgment; Models, Psychological; Psychophysics
Correspondence Address: Eyman, R.K.; Pacific State Hosp., , Pomona, CA, United States

Title: Clarification and evaluation of the two-factor theory of job satisfaction
Authors with affiliations: King, N., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Explicates and evaluates 5 distinct versions of the 2-factor theory of job satisfaction. It is concluded that (a) 2 of these versions are invalid, as they are not supported by any empirical studies; (b) another version is invalid, as its alleged empirical support merely reflects E coding biases; and (c) the validities of the remaining 2 versions are, at present, indeterminate, as they have not been adequately tested in studies where defensive biases inherent in certain self-report measures are eliminated. These conclusions are discussed in terms of the principle of multiple operationalism, and a method of testing the 2 indeterminate versions is suggested. (41 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: 2-factor theory of job satisfaction, validity of 5 versions
Correspondence Address: King, N.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Imagery in children's learning: A symposium
Authors with affiliations: Reese, H.W., U. Kansas
Abstract: Introduces a symposium which includes articles by A. Alla Paivio, W. Rohwer, H. Reese, & D. Palermo (see 44:8). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: imagery in children's learning, introduction to symposium

Title: Imagery in children's learning: Discussion
Affiliations: Pennsylvania State U., Lab. for the Study of the Symbolic Processes
Authors with affiliations: Palermo, D.S., Pennsylvania State U., Lab. for the Study of the Symbolic Processes
Abstract: Discusses papers by A. Paivio, H. W. Reese, and W. D. Rohwer (see 44:8) in the context of the revolutionary changes that appear to be taking place within the field of psychology. It is noted that imagery which these researchers have shown to be an extremely potent variable in a number of different experimental situations is an anomaly for behaviorism which therefore makes it difficult to provide a satisfactory theoretical account of its effects. Present theoretical efforts have failed to account for all of the data, but an hypothesis involving the leveling of figurative conceptions, which was advanced and rejected by Reese, may hold promise of accounting for these data and additional data presented here. (41 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: imagery in children's learning

Title: Current research in the frequency of dream recall
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, D.B., U. Texas
Abstract: Reviews the correlational and experimental research of the last 15 yr. on factors associated with the frequency of dream recall. The domain of dream recall is established as a broadly defined range of perceptual, conceptual, and affective experiences reported by Ss in studies using questionnaire, diary, and sleep-interruption methods. Frequency of dream recall is affected by physiological, methodological, and psychological factors. The importance of studying the association of narrowly defined, theoretically related personality variables and the frequency of specific types of dream reports obtained by different methods is emphasized. (41 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: experimental research; frequency of dream recall, correlational &

Title: Some applications of adaptation-level theory to aversive behavior
Authors with affiliations: Quinsey, V.L., U. Massachusetts
Abstract: Reviews learning experiments to demonstrate that adaptation-level (AL) theory qualitatively accounts for several phenomena in the area of aversive behavior: (a) adaptation and contrast effects, (b) the attenuation of an aversive event's effectiveness found when its intensity is gradually increased, and (c) the correspondence of performance to the average reinforcement intensity when the reinforcers vary in intensity. Perceptual effects are sometimes overshadowed by conditioning processes, especially in studies where shock is given before a learning task. It is concluded that AL theory is useful in understanding aversive behavior, although parametric investigations and subsequent quantitative applications of the model are needed. (41 ref.). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: adaptation-level theory, applications; aversive behavior &

Title: On the functional significance of imagery
Authors with affiliations: Paivio, A., U. Western Ontario, London, Canada
Abstract: Briefly reviews the historical background of the concept of imagery, focusing on its postulated role in learning and memory. A general overview of contemporary theoretical and operational approaches to the problem is presented, and a review of studies that illustrate 1 specific approach in which imagery is operationally defined in terms of stimulus meaning. The implications of these and other findings are discussed in relation to children's learning and possible developmental changes in imaginal and verbal symbolic processes generally. (37 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: imagery, role in learning &; memory, review
Correspondence Address: Paivio, A.; U. Western Ontario, London, Canada

Title: Images and pictures in children's learning: Research results and educational implications
Authors with affiliations: Rohwer Jr., W.D., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Reviews experiments that pertain to the issue of the role of imagery in children's learning including those concerned with: (a) properties of learning items, (b) properties of the elaboration of learning items, and (c) properties of elaboration instructions. The relevant evidence is viewed developmentally, and it is concluded that the capacity for deriving optimal benefit from verbal modes of representation emerges earlier in children's learning processes than the capacity for deriving optimal benefit from pictorial modes of representation. (29 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: educational implications; images &; pictures in children's learning, research &
Correspondence Address: Rohwer Jr., W.D.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Imagery and contextual meaning
Authors with affiliations: Reese, H.W., U. Kansas
Abstract: Considers 6 explanations of the hypothesis that imagery facilitates paired-associate performance less than sentences in younger children, but equally in older children: (a) deficit in verbalization (images facilitate performance only if described verbally); (b) defective visual memory (verbal material is remembered better than visual); (c) production deficiency (verbal mediators are produced but not images); (d) mediation deficiency (verbal and imaginal mediators are produced, but only verbal mediate); (e) leveling ("leveling" of the image of the stimulus-response interaction into separate images of the stimulus and response destroys the stimulus-response association); and (f) failure to "read" (failure to observe the association depicted in the imagery condition). Evidence from previous studies which favors the last interpretation is cited. (39 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: contextual meaning in children, age differences; imagery &

Title: Man versus model of man: A rationale, plus some evidence, for a method of improving on clinical inferences
Affiliations: Research Inst., OR Eugene,, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goldberg, L.R., Research Inst., OR Eugene,, United States
Abstract: Clinical psychologists, physicians, and other professionals are typically called upon to combine cues to arrive at some diagnostic or prognostic decision. Mathematical representations of such clinical judges can often be constructed to capture critical aspects of their judgmental strategies. An analysis of the characteristics of such models permits a specification of the conditions under which the model itself will be a more valid predictor than will the man from whom it was derived. To ascertain whether such conditions are met in natural clinical decision making, data were reanalyzed from P. E. Meehl's (see 34:3) study of the judgments of 29 clinical psychologists attempting to differentiate psychotic from neurotic patients on the basis of their MMPI profiles. Results of these analyses indicate that for this diagnostic task models of the men are generally more valid than the men themselves. Moreover, the finding occurred even when the models were constructed on a small set of cases, and then man and model competed on a completely new set. (29 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: discrimination of psychotic vs. neurotic patients, MMPI, clinicians' judgment vs. diagnostic model
Correspondence Address: Goldberg, L.R.; Research Inst., OR Eugene,, United States

Title: Comparison of the biometrical genetical, MAVA, and classical approaches to the analysis of the human behavior
Authors with affiliations: Jinks, J.L., U. Birmingham, England, United Kingdom; Fulker, D.W.
Abstract: Describes the techniques which can be used in the analysis of human behavior by the methods of biometrical genetics and compares them with those of the Multiple Abstract Variance Analysis, and other approaches. These techniques are applied to a number of personality and cognitive measures using published data. Underlying assumptions of the analyses used are discussed and tests of significance for departure from them are demonstrated. Although data were often inadequate, the techniques provided new information on the gene action controlling the measures and on their evolution. It is concluded that the outcome of the reanalyses indicates the unique value of the biometrical approach. (44 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: analysis of human twin &; familial data, biometrical genetical vs. Multiple Abstract Variance Analysis vs. classical approaches

Title: The effects of epidermal hydration and sodium reabsorption on palmar skin potential
Authors with affiliations: Fowles, D.C., U. Oklahoma; Venables, P.H.
Abstract: Describes 2 factors important in measurements of palmar skin potentials: (a) Epidermal hydration, which occurs when aqueous solutions with low salt content are applied to the skin, promotes swelling of the epidermis and closure of the sweat gland pores. Poral closure, in turn, reduces the measured potential by increasing the resistance between the electrode and the negative potential in the duct, and probably also by altering ductal reabsorption. (b) The reabsorption of sodium from the sweat passing through the duct generates a transductal potential in which the duct lumen is negative relative to the interstitial fluid. This active transport of sodium under the control of the pituitary-adrenal axis may account for the large negative potentials recorded from the human palm. It may also account for the large positive waves recorded in humans. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: palmar skin potential, epidermal hydration &; sodium reabsorption

Title: Brief critique of the meaning and reliability of "accurate empathy" ratings
Authors with affiliations: Chinsky, J.M., U. Connecticut; Rappaport, J.
Abstract: Questions the meaning of "accurate empathy" ratings and suggests that ratings may reflect a quality other than that defined by the scale. Reliability estimates may be related to the number of therapists being rated, and are demonstrated to be inflated by the use of nonindependent judgments. Some methodological suggestions which would insure a more accurate appraisal of the scale's reliability are proposed, although the meaning of the scale remains in question. (11 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: accurate empathy ratings of therapists, critique on meaning &; reliability

Title: Early infantile autism: Diagnosis, etiology, and treatment
Affiliations: Eastern State School and Hosp., Autistic Children's Unit, Trevose, Pa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ward, A.J., Eastern State School and Hosp., Autistic Children's Unit, Trevose, Pa, United States
Abstract: Presents an overview of the syndrome of early infantile autism (EIA) which reveals a general state of confusion in the recent literature. Examination of the problem of diagnosis suggests the presence of significant amounts of organic dysfunction in many Ss labeled as "autistic." The following diagnostic criteria are suggested: (a) lack of object relations, (b) lack of use of speech for communication, (c) maintenance of sameness via stereotypic behavior, and (d) lack of neurologic dysfunction. A study of the question of etiology disclosed that many articles emphasize the effects of either overstimulation or a lack of stimulation at early developmental stages, and discuss the importance of the intactness of the perceptual apparatus. The existence of 2 subgroups of autistic Ss who could be described as "organic" and "psychogenic" was again revealed. Evaluation of modes of treatment revealed few successful reports except when a very active, intrusive, and pleasant therapeutic approach was used. Hypotheses on etiology and treatment, from an ego-psychology point of view, are proposed. (31 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: early infantile autism, diagnosis &; etiology &; treatment
Index Keywords: article; autism; child parent relation; developmental disorder; differential diagnosis; ego; female; human; infant; male; play therapy; psychotherapy; Autistic Disorder; Developmental Disabilities; Diagnosis, Differential; Ego; Female; Human; Infant; Male; Parent-Child Relations; Play Therapy; Psychotherapy
Correspondence Address: Ward, A.J.; Eastern State School and Hosp., , Trevose, Pa, United States

Title: Comments on Friedman's rm procedure
Authors with affiliations: Breen, L., York U., Toronto, Ont., Canada; Gaito, J.
Abstract: Discusses cautions which should be observed with respect to H. Friedman's (see 43:1) rm procedure. To clarify these aspects the rm method of magnitude estimation is compared to the utility coefficient (Uc) procedure. Both methods can be used to determine the magnitude of the components which are present in significant main and interaction effects. The rm procedure does not, however, provide magnitude statements for error sources whereas the Uc method does. Also rm's are overly sensitive to changes in the mathematical models underlying various analysis of variance designs, thus should not be used in designs where the F ratios are based on more than 1 error term. Additional caution must be exercised in testing the difference between 2 rm's. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: comments on H. Friedman's rm procedure
Correspondence Address: Breen, L.; York U., Toronto, Ont., Canada

Title: Amendation of Cohen's cautions regarding the measurement of profile similarity
Authors with affiliations: Block, J., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Notes that J. Cohen's (see 43:6) rc, a profile similarity coefficient invariant over variable reflection, is useful when normative data are being employed, but for ipsatively collected data or data otherwise transformed so that the profile means of all individuals are identical, rc reduces to the ordinary and more convenient product-moment correlation coefficient. Accordingly, Q-factor analyses and related procedures predicated upon the use of r applied to properly ipsatized data are not jeopardized by the problems that Cohen notes in his article. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: measurement of profile similarity, amendation of J. Cohen's cautions
Correspondence Address: Block, J.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Title: Note on Evans and Anastasio on the analysis of covariance
Authors with affiliations: Sprott, D.A., U. Waterloo, Ont., Canada
Abstract: Discusses conditions for a valid analysis of covariance emphasizing that it is not necessary for the treatment effect and covariate to be uncorrelated in the observed experiment. If this were a required condition, practically all analyses of covariance would be invalid. The required condition is that the treatment is known a priori not to affect the covariate. The logical and mathematical ramifications of this are discussed. If the treatment does influence the covariate, the calculations are the same but extreme care must be exercised in interpreting the results. Examples are cited to show that in many cases meaningful results are obtained and an analysis of covariance is still what is required. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: analysis of covariance, treatment effect &; covariate, note on S. Evans &; E. Anastasio
Correspondence Address: Sprott, D.A.; U. Waterloo, Ont., Canada

Title: On the use of memorial techniques to assess syntactic structures
Authors with affiliations: Fillenbaum, S., U. North Carolina
Abstract: Questions inferences about underlying syntactic structures which often have been drawn on the basis of indirect assessment, as by an analysis of confusions in a memorial task, because (a) the sort of syntactic analysis required in a memory task may differ in important respects from that required for full understanding, and (b) such data provide information simultaneously about possible underlying structures and about memorial and retrieval processes; generally it will not be possible to factor this information into its components. 1 example is examined in some detail. Yes/No questions appear to be very similar if one considers confusions in a memorial task, and such data have been regarded as corroborating a grammatical analysis that assigns these questions the same underlying structure. Upon more direct assessment by use of paraphrase, equivalence judgment, and prediction procedures that call for careful scrutiny and full understanding these sentence constructions are found to be rather different from each other. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: syntactic structure, confusions in memory tasks

Authors: Mueller E.F., Kasl S.V., Brooks G.W., Cobb S.
Title: Psychosocial correlates of serum urate levels
Affiliations: U. Michigan, Inst. for Social, Research
Authors with affiliations: Mueller, E.F., U. Michigan, Inst. for Social, Research; Kasl, S.V.; Brooks, G.W.; Cobb, S.
Abstract: Reviews recent studies which suggest that uric acid, the end product of purine metabolism in man, or its precursor is related to social class, achievement, and achievement-oriented behavior. There is also evidence that serum uric acid levels change in response to socially and psychologically stressful situations. Problems of uric acid metabolism and the main variables affecting urate levels in the blood are discussed. The possibility that uric acid or its precursors act as stimulants of CNS activity is considered and the research problems most relevant to future progress in this area are discussed, especially the need to clarify the causal relations between uric acid, behavior, and environmental stimulation. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: achievement &; achievement-oriented behavior; serum urate levels, social class &
Index Keywords: uric acid; achievement; article; behavior; blood; central nervous system; human; leadership; mental stress; metabolism; social class; Achievement; Behavior; Central Nervous System; Human; Leadership; Social Class; Social Mobility; Stress, Psychological; Uric Acid

Title: Altruism: An examination of the concept and a review of the literature
Authors with affiliations: Krebs, D.L., Harvard U
Abstract: Reviews literature relating to altruism and suggests that the study of altruism is important at 3 levels: (a) as it relates to the main goal of socialization, (b) to a core attribute of personality, and (c) to theories concerned with human nature. Independent variables associated with altruism are organized in a 2 * 4 framework on the basis of the source of experimental measurement and level of generality. Characteristics of the benefactor and characteristics of the recipient are categorized as state variables, trait variables, social roles and demographic attributes, and characteristics influenced by social norms. Research at each level is critically reviewed. Positive and negative affective states, and states induced by the observation of models are found to influence the altruism of benefactors; and dependency and interpersonal attractiveness are found to influence the altruism-eliciting capacity of recipients. Research relevant to personality traits is criticized. Effects are found for sex, age, ordinal position, social class, and nationality in relation to benefactors, and for friendship status, ingroup affiliation, and social class in relation to recipients. The normative level of analysis is criticized. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: altruism, socialization &; personality traits &; theories of human nature

Authors: Loveless N.E., Brebner J., Hamilton P.
Title: Bisensory presentation of information
Authors with affiliations: Loveless, N.E., U. Dundee, Scotland, United Kingdom; Brebner, J.; Hamilton, P.
Abstract: Simultaneous presentation of functionally identical signals in 2 sensory modalities may theoretically yield a gain of information from increased input redundancy. The potential gain from probability summation depends, however, on the strategy adopted in integrating information, and may be further complicated by sensory interaction. Review of the literature on intersensory effects suggests that these in turn may be due to several distinct mechanisms. The difficulties of designing experiments to distinguish the various theoretical models are discussed, and the results of 4 experiments are presented. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: bisensory simultaneous presentation of information, probability summation &; information gain; strategy &

Title: Conditioned appetitive drive states: Empirical evidence and theoretical status
Authors with affiliations: Cravens, R.W., U. Illinois; Renner, K.E.
Abstract: The literature on conditioned appetitive drive states reveals that a majority of the studies have produced no evidence for appetitive conditioning. An evaluation of the procedures used in these studies shows that the minimum necessary conditions for obtaining appetitive conditioning have not been met. Alternative theoretical considerations which bear upon the sufficient conditions for obtaining conditioned appetitive drives are discussed. It is concluded that a simple parallel between appetitive and aversive conditioning processes should be avoided. (25 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: conditioned appetitive drive states, procedures &; evidence &; theory

Title: The use of nonlinear, noncompensatory models in decision making
Affiliations: U. Chicago, Graduate School of Business
Authors with affiliations: Einhorn, H.J., U. Chicago, Graduate School of Business
Abstract: Discusses the factors that affect decision making and presented a theoretical unity model developed to approximate the conjunctive and disjunctive models and to provide for part of the priori classification scheme necessary to go from a purely ipsative model of behavior to some more general scheme. These models are shown to give a better fit to certain decision data than the linear model, and the factors affecting their use and implications are discussed. (28 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: decision making, nonlinear noncompensatory models
Index Keywords: article; clinical psychology; decision making; human; model; Decision Making; Human; Models, Psychological; Psychology, Clinical

Title: Altruistic behavior by children
Authors with affiliations: Bryan, J.H., Northwestern U; London, P.
Abstract: Reviews studies concerning self-sacrificing behavior by children and adolescents and examines the role of behavioral example, reinforcement, and personality characteristics on donation behavior and interpersonal attraction. (39 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: adolescents; altruistic behavior &; interpersonal attraction, example &; personality, children &; reinforcement &
Index Keywords: article; child; female; human; male; model; morality; personality; reinforcement; social behavior; social psychology; socialization; Child; Female; Human; Male; Models, Psychological; Morals; Personality; Reinforcement (Psychology); Social Behavior; Social Conformity; Socialization

Title: Channel capacity in absolute judgment tasks: An artifact of information bias?
Authors with affiliations: MacRae, A.W., University Coll., North Wales, Bangor
Abstract: When T, an estimate of information transmission (T), is calculated from experimental data it may suffer a number of biases, all of which tend to inflate T and become more severe as the input information H(S) is increased. The effects of these biases on well-known absolute judgment experiments are examined with the conclusion that bias is responsible for (a) the alleged advantage of having large numbers of responses available, i.e., optimum transmission is in fact given when there are equal numbers of stimuli and responses; and (b) the frequently reported asymptotic increase in T with increasing H(S). The corrected transmission curve has an initial increase followed by a decline. People therefore behave as channels of limited, but not fixed, capacity. (22 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: absolute judgment task channel capacity &; information bias
Correspondence Address: MacRae, A.W.; University Coll., North Wales, Bangor

Title: Racial "experimenter effects" in experimentation, testing, interviewing, and psychotherapy
Authors with affiliations: Sattler, J.M., San Diego State Coll
Abstract: A review of studies concerned with the "Es' " race indicates the following: (a) Physiological responsiveness is affected more by the Ss' racial attitudes than by the Es' race. (b) White Es can impede or enhance Negro college students' performance on tasks, but are more likely to impede or affect Negro children's performance. (c) Es' race affects Ss' picture and doll preferences, but may not influence their scores on intelligence tests and personality measures. (d) Positive attitudes toward Negroes can be induced by a Negro E or a Negro-white E team. (e) Respondents give socially desirable responses to interviewers of other races, except when the interviewers occupy a high-status role. (f) Negro clients prefer Negro counselors. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: interviewing &; psychotherapy; racial E effects, experimentation &; testing &

Title: Concerning introspective "knowledge"
Authors with affiliations: Natsoulas, T., U. California, Davis, United States
Abstract: Discusses the nature of introspective awareness, those events by whose occurrence acquire knowledge of our own mental episodes. Present orienting attitudes towards mental episodes and awareness of them are made explicit, as are some of the basic concepts to be used. Introspective awarenesses are discussed from the perspective of S; afterimages, pains, sense impressions, visual contents, and thoughts are examined as contents of introspective awarenesses. The intrinsic or factual character of such awarenesses is considered from the perspectives of 3 materialist theories: (a) that of B. F. Skinner, which claims introspective awarenesses to be verbal responses; (b) that which claims that all awarenesses are thoughts; and (c) that which interprets introspection (and perception) as an instantaneous acquiring of belief or belieflike central states. (59 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: introspective awareness &; knowledge of mental &; perceptual processes, theory
Index Keywords: article; cognition; drug effect; human; perception; thinking; Cognition; Human; Perception; Thinking
Correspondence Address: Natsoulas, T.; U. California, Davis, United States

Title: Cognition, preparation, and sensory-evoked potentials
Authors with affiliations: Karlin, L., New York U
Abstract: Reviews and reinterprets experiments reporting enhancement of averaged sensory-evoked potentials, resulting from the effects of various cognitive aspects of stimulation, in terms of 2 hypotheses which refer, respectively, to (a) development of preparation before, and (b) reactive change in preparation after presentation of critical stimuli. The possibility is examined that certain slow voltage changes, such as contingent negative variation and other so-called "readiness" potentials, are associated with reactive change and produce the positive enhancement in evoked potentials as reported in many of these experiments. (41 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.

Title: A latent-structure model for answering personal questions
Affiliations: Educational Testing Service, Princeton, N.J, United States
Authors with affiliations: Damarin, F., Educational Testing Service, Princeton, N.J, United States
Abstract: Shows that a latent-structure model for answering true-flase questionnaire items predicts a circular ordering among MMPI scales used in a study by J. S. Wiggins and V. R. Lovell (see 39:6). A circular ordering can be demonstrated, but certain systematic departures from the predicted effects also occur. The data suggest the operation of 3 latent traits: self-descriptive accuracy, favorable bias, and a tendency to endorse items that are neutral in the sense of being unrelated to the other 2 traits. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.

Title: A general linear model for studying growth
Affiliations: Educational Testing Service, Princeton, N.J, United States
Authors with affiliations: Werts, C.E., Educational Testing Service, Princeton, N.J, United States; Linn, R.L.
Abstract: Evaluates the implications of using raw difference and residual change scores within the framework of a linear regression model which is assumed to represent the determinants of change. Given the regression model and a determinant of change (Z) other than initial status (X), use of residual change scores results in biased estimates of the influence of Z on change when X and Z are correlated. Parallel results are obtained when the measures are treated as error free and when they are treated as fallible. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.

Title: Identification of creativity: The individual
Authors with affiliations: Dellas, M., Eastern Michigan U; Gaier, E.L.
Abstract: Reviews creativity research within the cognitive and personological investigative orientations on 5 parameters of creativity as they affect the individual: (a) intellectual factors and cognitive styles associated with creativity, (b) creativity as related/unrelated to intelligence, (c) personality aspects of creativity, (d) the potential creative, and (e) motivational characteristics associated with creativity. Despite differences in age, cultural background, area of operation or eminence, a particular consistent constellation of psychological trait emerges. These persons also appear distinguished more by interests, attitudes, and drives, rather than by intellectual abilities. The assessment of creative potential should include singular intellectual characteristics, cognitive styles, and personality variables. Creativity research pursued on the basis of compound criteria from disparate psychological levels may present more valid findings, and contribute to the resolution of conceptual dilemmas. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.

Title: Marriage research and conflict: An integrative review
Affiliations: Weston Coll., School of Theology, Cambridge, Mass, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barry, W.A., Weston Coll., School of Theology, Cambridge, Mass, United States
Abstract: Used conflict theory and research to explain findings as a 1st step toward a more generalized theoretical explanation based on object-relations subtheories of personality. The importance of homogamy in assuring value consensus is noted. The importance of personality strengths in husbands is explained as a function of wives' needs for security and support during the difficult period of transition to being a wife and mother. The healthier the husband's personality, the more capable he is of being emotionally supportive and thus the less likely is severe and destructive conflict. (2 p. ref.) Title: The psychological refractory period effect: Only half the double-stimulation story?
Authors with affiliations: Herman, L.M., U. Hawaii; Kantowitz, B.H.
Abstract: Stressed that a major source of empirical data on RT to the 1st of the 2 successive stimuli (RT1) in the double-stimulation psychological refractory period (PRP) task has been overlooked. Each reviewed theory of the PRP effect was extended to a prediction of RT1 characteristics in the PRP task. These predictions were evaluated against data from some PRP studies having reported RT1, and against data from a set of double-stimulation RT studies in which no response was required to the 2nd stimulus. Predictions of all theories but 1 either failed or were weak. Since this 1 theory was capable of accounting for both RT1 and RT2 data, it was considered preferable to the remaining theories for explanation of PRP (RT2) effects. Both RT1 and RT2 effects in double-stimulation tasks were considered to reflect the interaction of response tendencies aroused by the 2 successive stimuli. (38 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: psychological refractory period, double stimulation reaction time task

Authors: Simons H.W., Berkowitz N.N., Moyer R.J.
Title: Similarity, credibility, and attitude change: A review and a theory
Authors with affiliations: Simons, H.W., Temple U; Berkowitz, N.N.; Moyer, R.J.
Abstract: Reviews findings from studies (including previously unsummarized "social attraction" research) linking types of source-receiver similarities (attitudinal and membership, relevant and irrelevant), bases for credibility (respect, attraction, trust), and attitude change. Contrary to prevalent formulations, it appears that: (a) certain dissimilarities have positive effects on attitude change; (b) irrelevant similarities have little effect; (c) although attitudinal similarity and attraction are linearly related, attraction may not contribute significantly to attitude change. A theory emphasizing perceived instrumentality of similarity-dissimilarity is offered to account for the findings. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1970 American Psychological Association.
