Title: Error rates for multiple comparison methods: Some evidence concerning the frequency of erroneous conclusions
Authors with affiliations: Petrinovich, L.F., U. California, Riverside, United States; Hardyck, C.D.
Abstract: 7 methods currently used for paired comparisons among all group means following analysis of variance were tested for sensitivity to violation of stated requirements. The t-test methods and the Duncan multiple range test were found to produce far more Type I errors under null conditions than is generally acceptable. The methods of H. Scheffe and J. W. Tukey produced the fewest Type I errors and are least susceptible to violation of requirements. Type II error rates for all methods were generated. The appropriate choice of error rate and multiple comparison method is discussed. (3l ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: error rates for multiple comparison methods in psychological research
Correspondence Address: Petrinovich, L.F.; U. California, Riverside, United States

Title: Animism revived
Authors with affiliations: Looft, W.R., Iowa State U; Bartz, W.H.
Abstract: Reviews the literature on animistic thought, beginning with the initial work by Piaget. In addition to the coverage of the empirical work, methodological and theoretical issues are discussed extensively, including methods of analysis, semantic problems and response bias the stage concept, and the influence of specific experiences. Animism in adults is also discussed and concluded to be not of the same character as that found in children. The suggestion is made that new conceptualizations of animism and improved methods of investigation are needed to stimulate further research efforts. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: animism, history of research &; theory

Title: Factor analysis of African abilities and attainments: Constructs across cultures
Authors with affiliations: Irvine, S.H., U. Bristol, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper is based on the results of experimental investigations in east and central Africa, involving field studies of over 5000 Ss. It illustrates the application of factorial analysis in the search for the psychological and descriptive meaning of test scores derived from African Ss taking tests adapted from those currently in use in western societies or standardized on African Ss. Results suggest that, although tests tend consistently to group themselves together in ways explicable in terms of Western constructs such as "g," v:ed, and n:ed, sources of variance exist unique to the environment of the society in which the tests are administered. Of particular note are the identification of an educational aptitude factor associated with males, and the less stable nature of perceptual and spatial factors. Discussion centers on the contribution of the study toward a cross-cultural interpretation of educational abilities in terms of a limited transfer of a value system in which the concept of intelligence is a key term. (48 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1969 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Western constructs in testing abilities of African Ss, construct validity, factor analysis
Correspondence Address: Irvine, S.H.; U. Bristol, England, United Kingdom

Title: Reversal of simultaneous lightness-contrast
Authors with affiliations: Steger, J.A., State U. New York, Albany
Abstract: Reviews the theoretical and experimental research on the reversal of simultaneous lightness-contrast (assimilation). H. Helson's differential stimulation hypothesis of contrast and assimilation is examined in view of recent research. It is concluded that before a quantitative formulation incorporating both simultaneous lightness-contrast and assimilation can be complete, research is needed to assess the contribution of (1) area-luminance functions, (2) mode of viewing, (3) contours and divisions, (4) perceptual set, (5) absolute levels of luminance in the viewing situation, (6) adaptation of the eye, and (7) the nature of the experimental stimuli used. (40 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: assimilation, needed research; simultaneous lightness-contrast reversal &
Correspondence Address: Steger, J.A.; State U. New York, Albany

Title: Differentiation theory and concept-shift behavior
Authors with affiliations: Tighe, T.J., Dartmouth Coll; Tighe, L.S.
Abstract: Reveals error in J. L. Wolff's (see 42:3) interpretation of the differentiation theory of concept-shift behavior. Logical, methodological, and empirical considerations are advanced which are of general importance for evaluation of the several theories of concept-shift learning. The differentiation analysis is clarified and reinforced. (17 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: differentiation theory of concept shift learning, criticism

Title: Pitfalls in data analysis and interpretation: A reply to Rosenthal
Affiliations: Medfield Foundation, Harding, Mass, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barber, T.X., Medfield Foundation, Harding, Mass, United States; Silver, M.J.
Abstract: Each objection raised in R. Rosenthal's (see 43:5) reply to T. X. Barber and M. J. Silver's (see 43:5) review is shown to be erroneous or misleading. Data are presented to show that (1) the p values that were not discussed in the Barber and Silver review were invalid and did not merit discussion, (2) Rosenthal's reply labeled as "replications" a series of contradictory studies that failed as replications, and (3) Rosenthal's reply presented overall ps from series of studies that were either invalid or misleading. Additional data are provided to support the following major conclusion of the Barber and Silver review: Although 12 studies showed that the results were significantly in line with the student expectancies, Rosenthal's contention that conscientious Es unintentionally and subtly influence Ss to proffer responses which confirm Es' expectancies has not as yet been conclusively demonstrated and replicated because such factors as intentionality, vague criteria, misrecording of responses, and fudging of data were not rigorously excluded. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: E bias effect, review, reply to comment
Correspondence Address: Barber, T.X.; Medfield Foundation, Harding, Mass, United States

Title: A correlational approach for measuring overlap of distributions and proportion of misclassification
Affiliations: Naval Personnel Research Activity, San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Curtis, E.W., Naval Personnel Research Activity, San Diego, CA, United States; Alf Jr., E.F.
Abstract: J. W. Tilton's overlap measure is inappropriate when the underlying relationship between the dichotomized variable, represented by 2 groups, and the continuous variable, on which the groups overlap, is assumed to be bivariate normal. Also, Tilton's measure is restricted to interpretation in terms of equal-sized distributions. 2 measures of overlap for the bivariate normal case are developed, 1 for interpretation in terms of equal-sized distributions, the other for interpretation in terms of the base-rate distributions. With underlying bivariate normality, the distributions are normal only when r is zero. Graphs are presented which show the relationships among r, overlap, and proportion of misclassification for various base rates. A table gives cutoffs that are optimum for prediction under these conditions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: measuring overlap of distributions &; proportion of misclassification, correlation
Correspondence Address: Curtis, E.W.; Naval Personnel Research Activity, San Diego, CA, United States

Title: Experimenter expectancy and the reassuring nature of the null hypothesis decision procedure
Authors with affiliations: Rosenthal, R., Harvard U
Abstract: By employing some form of a null hypothesis decision procedure, 12 of the studies summarized by T. X. Barber and M. J. Silver (see 43:5) were judged to demonstrate expectancy effects. The combined p of the results of these studies was less than 1/1,000,0002. When the results of the studies judged by Barber and Silver not demonstrate clearly the effects of E expectancy were considered separately, the combined p was 6/1,000,000. For all studies combined, p was less than 1/1,000,000(2+x) with a median 2 tailed p < .1. Such results provide little reassurance that the effects of Es' expectancies are not general, robust, nor serious enough to warrant the use of procedures designed to permit their control and/or assessment. Methods for the analysis of data selected by Barber and Silver are discussed in terms of their differential value for the analysis of single experiments and runs of experiments. An appendix is attached to add information omitted from the presentation by Barber and Silver. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: E bias effect, analysis of studies by null hypothesis decision procedure, comment

Title: The Hawthorne dogma
Authors with affiliations: Sommer, R., U. California, Davis, United States
Abstract: The Hawthorne effect is generally considered an E error to be avoided in psychological research. The view is largely conditioned by a bias toward single variable laboratory research. In field studies Hawthorne effects are the rule rather than the exception. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Hawthorne effect in experimental research
Correspondence Address: Sommer, R.; U. California, Davis, United States

Title: Imbalanced scales and correlation between agreeing and content scores: Pitfalls for the unwary
Affiliations: Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Peizer, D.B., Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Los Angeles, CA, United States
Abstract: Difficulties in estimating correlation between agreeing and content scores may be overcome by correcting variance and covariance terms entering into the computations of the correlation coefficient for bias. Least squares estimates of agreeing and content scores are generally more efficient than those obtained by artificially deleting items in order to obtain a balanced scale. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: content scores, bias in correlation coefficient; estimating correlation between agreeing &
Correspondence Address: Peizer, D.B.; Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences, Los Angeles, CA, United States

Title: Some theoretical considerations of bilingual development
Authors with affiliations: Riegel, K.F., U. Michigan
Abstract: Discusses 3 aspects of bilingual development. 1st, the environmental, linguistic conditions that impinge upon a growing individual are described. 2nd, changes in the set of word relations are contrasted with changes in the vocabulary. 3rd, relations also form the basis from which semantic and syntactic classes are derived. The free ends of 2 intersecting relations represent the minimal condition for the definition of a class. As a most stringent criterion, the free branches are to be symmetrically related. Examples of complex networks and different types of relations are given and the possibilities discussed of deriving word classes empirically, of defining meaning operationally, and of applying digraph theory for their analysis. The ambiguity of function words and interlingual syntactic transformations concludes the discussion of bilingual development. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: bilingual development, linguistic environment &; semantic &; syntactic classes; word relations &

Title: Methods for determining equivalence of measures
Authors with affiliations: Gulliksen, H., Princeton U
Abstract: The importance of the problem of equivalence of various methods of measuring an underlying variable or a hypothetical trait has been reorganized in diverse fields such as animal experimentation, attitude measurement, and mental tests. A variety of solutions has been developed, ranging from a criterion for strict interchangeability of scores to factor methods for comparing multifactor batteries of measures and multidimensional scaling. The available methods have not been widely used by Es. The use of appropriate experimental and analytical procedures for assessing the degree of equivalence of measures is necessary to clarify the nature of intervening variables (hypothetical constructs or basic abstracts) such as learning ability, preferences, attitudes, thirst, and hunger. (57 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: methods for determining equivalence of measures of variables

Title: Bayesian synthesis of clinical and statistical prediction
Authors with affiliations: Pankoff, L.D., Washington U; Roberts, H.V.
Abstract: The long-standing controversy in the human counseling professions over how predictions should be made whether by clinical or statistical methods is examined in light of the emerging Bayesian orientation in statistics. The Bayesian framework yields predictions based upon a synthesis of the best features of methods often though incompatible: the judgment of the clinician and the statistician's procedures for learning from experience. The Bayesian approach with examples from the clinical-statistical literature, and a new case study demonstrates how the synthesis may be accomplished. The circumstances under which clinical and statistical methods may be difficult to synthesize is described. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: clinical prediction, Bayesian synthesis of clinical &; statistical considerations

Title: Response feedback and learning
Authors with affiliations: Adams, J.A., U. Illinois
Abstract: Concerns controversies about sensory feedback which have contributed to the divisions that have marked stimulus-response and sign-significate learning theories. Studies and ideas about response feedback and learning are examined, and conclusions about the present state of empirical knowledge and theory are drawn. Closed-loop theory, with its emphasis on feedback and error detection, has been centered mainly in engineering and biological fields, but it is now emerging with implications for learning. The usefulness of closed-loop theory for old and new behavioral phenomena is discussed. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: sensory feedback, stimulus-response &; sign-significate learning theories, consideration of closed-loop theory

Title: Fact, fiction, and the experimenter bias effect
Affiliations: Medfield Foundation, Harding, Mass, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barber, T.X., Medfield Foundation, Harding, Mass, United States; Silver, M.J.
Abstract: Critically analyzes 31 studies which attempted to demonstrate that Es' expectancies and desires significantly affect the experimental outcome (E bias effect). The majority of studies do not clearly demonstrate the effect. Many of these studies are criticized for inadequacies in the analysis of results, e.g., failure to perform an overall statistical analysis to exclude the null hypothesis and failure to avoid probability pyramiding when postmortem tests are performed. 2 conclusions are drawn: (1) The E bias effect appears to be more difficult to demonstrate and less pervasive than was implied in previous reviews in this journal. (2) In those instances in which the effect was obtained, it was apparently due to one or more of the following: the student Es misjudged, misrecorded or misreported the results; they verbally reinforced their Ss for expected responses; or they intentionally or unintentionally transmitted their expectancies and desires by paralinguistic or kinesic cues. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: E bias effect, review
Correspondence Address: Barber, T.X.; Medfield Foundation, Harding, Mass, United States

Title: Equity theory as a predictor of productivity and work quality
Authors with affiliations: Lawler, E.E., Yale U
Abstract: The predictions of equity theory with respect to the effects of inequitable payment were compared and contrasted with those made by expectancy theory. The literature relevant to testing equity theory's predictions about 4 inequitable payment situations was considered, i.e., the piece-rate overpayment, hourly overpayment, piece-rate underpayment, and hourly underpayment situations. The methodological problems with the research designed to test equity theory were considered. It was concluded that the data from the 2 hourly situations do not make a convincing case for the view that equity theory is needed in order to explain how people react to hourly over- and underpayment. Equity theory did appear to be useful in explaining the results of the studies concerned with piece-rate over- and underpayment. It was suggested that by including some concept of equity into the more general expectancy-theory approach the results for the piece-rate situation could best be explained. It was also suggested that perceived equity might be treated as 1 factor that influences the valence or attractiveness of rewards. (30 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: payment equity vs. expectancy theories, prediction of productivity &; work quality

Title: Mirror-image stimulation
Authors with affiliations: Gallup Jr., G.G., Tulane U
Abstract: Analyzes the psychological properties of an organism's own reflection in a mirror, and discusses methodological problems associated with mirror research. Many organisms are responsive to mirrors, and reflected images are examined in terms of motivational and social stimulus properties which have been found to extend across a wide variety of species. Reinforcing properties of mirrors are interpreted in terms of novel stimulation with social stimulus overtones. Stimulus change and mimicry are 2 of the most prominent characteristics of an organism's mirror image. An animal in front of a mirror is instrumental in producing changes in the behavior of the reflected image, yet most organisms respond to mirrors as if their image represented another animal. In an attempt to conceptualize both the human and animal data, responses to mirrors and dimensionalized into other- and self-directed behaviors. Implications of mirrors for abnormal behavior and psychotherapy are considered. (63 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: human; response to mirror images, other- &; self-directed behavior, animal &
Index Keywords: aggression; animal; animal behavior; behavior; human; identity; imitation; instrumental conditioning; mental disease; reinforcement; review; self concept; social behavior; vision; Aggression; Animal; Behavior; Behavior, Animal; Conditioning, Operant; Human; Identification (Psychology); Imitative Behavior; Psychopathology; Reinforcement (Psychology); Self Concept; Social Facilitation; Visual Perception

Title: A cross-sequential study of age changes in cognitive behavior
Authors with affiliations: Schaie, K.W., West Virginia U; Strother, C.R.
Abstract: Previous cross-sectional and longitudinal studies of age changes over the adult life span have reported contradictory age gradients. The apparent contradiction was assessed by means of a new research design, called the cross-sequential method, which involves the repeated measurement of members of a cross-sectional sample. The Science Research Associates Primary Mental Abilities Test (PMA) and Schaie's Test of Behavioral Rigidity (TBR) were administered to a stratified-random sample of 500 Ss with quotas of 25 men and 25 women in each 5-yr age interval from 20-70 yr. 7 yr. later all Ss who could be located were contacted and 302 Ss were retested. Significant cross-sectional age changes were found for all variables studied, but longitudinal age changes occurred for all cohorts only for those variables where response speed was of importance. Analysis of the comparative age gradients suggest that age changes over time within a given individual appear to be much smaller than differences between cohorts and that the steep textbook age gradients represent no more than the effects of increased environmental opportunity and/or genetic changes in the species. Further implications with respect to revisions in current thinking on adult age changes are discussed. (20 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Primary Mental Abilities Test &; Test of Behavioral Rigidity, age changes, 20-70 yr. olds
Index Keywords: adult; aged; aging; analysis of variance; article; cognition; cultural factor; female; human; male; reaction time; Adult; Aged; Aging; Analysis of Variance; Cognition; Cross-Cultural Comparison; Female; Human; Male; Middle Age; Reaction Time

Title: Interpreting perceptual reports
Authors with affiliations: Natsoulas, T., U. California, Davis, United States
Abstract: Elaborates on a basis presented in an article by T. Natsoulas (see 41:6) for differentiating phenomenal and cognitive perceptual reports, in terms of their informativeness concerning causal determinants. It is argued that what a perceptual report is about and asserts must be distinguished from the cause which defines it as phenomenal or cognitive. Experiential and situational bases for what a report is about and asserts are discussed and rejected. It is concluded that the referent of a perceptual report is determined by how S interprets the perceptual experience which gives rise to his report. Some attention is given to the nature of interpretations of perceptual experience. Implications of the study for the original differentiation between phenomenal and cognitive reports are discussed. (31 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: phenomenal vs. cognitive perceptual reports, informativeness of causal determinants
Index Keywords: cognition; human; perception; review; Cognition; Human; Perception
Correspondence Address: Natsoulas, T.; U. California, Davis, United States

Title: Current methodology in research on the etiology of schizophrenia: Serious difficulties which suggest the use of the high-risk-group method
Authors with affiliations: Mednick, S.A., Psykologisk Inst., Kommunehospitalet, Copenhagen, Denmark; McNeil, T.F.
Abstract: Reviews difficulties of current research models, e.g., (1) testing the schizophrenic (S) seems to yield more information on the effects of consequents of the illness than on origins, (2) the family of S is changed by the experience so that its original pathogenic role is obscured, (3) studying Ss' childhood records had advantages but suffers from sampling problems and data insufficiencies. Longitudinal study of young normal populations at high risk for schizophrenia can detect distinguishing premorbid characteristics of Ss who suffer breakdown. These premorbid characteristics may be used in planning research on the prevention of breakdown. Conclusions concerning causes can best be developed from such experimental-manipulative prevention research models rather than correlative research models. (50 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: methodology in research on etiology of schizophrenia
Index Keywords: human; model; psychology; research; review; schizophrenia; technique; Human; Methods; Models, Psychological; Research; Schizophrenia; Schizophrenic Psychology
Correspondence Address: Mednick, S.A.; Psykologisk Inst., , Copenhagen, Denmark

Title: Survey of electromechanical devices for behavior modification
Affiliations: U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schwitzgebel, R.L., U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Abstract: Approximately 50 electromechanical devices presently employed for psychotherapeutic purposes are reviewed under 5 categories of function: monitoring and recording, stimulus transformation, neurological alteration, consequence scheduling, and prompting and teaching. The experimental nature, and in some cases the dubious value, of such devices is noted. It is argued, however, that instrumentation in clinical and social psychology might substantially improve the reliability of certain behavior modification procedures which at present often involve such unmeasured variation that adequate replication is impossible. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: electromechanical devices used in psychotherapy, evaluation
Index Keywords: avoidance behavior; behavior therapy; electric shock; electronics; human; instrumental conditioning; instrumentation; neurophysiology; psychotherapy; review; tape recorder; Avoidance Learning; Behavior Therapy; Conditioning, Operant; Electronics, Medical; Electroshock; Human; Neurophysiology; Psychotherapy; Tape Recording
Correspondence Address: Schwitzgebel, R.L.; U. California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Grief: Its nature and significance
Authors with affiliations: Averill, J.R., U. California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Analyzes bereavement behavior from cultural, biological, and psychological perspectives. Mourning is distinguished from grief and the relationship between them examined. Mourning is considered to represent conventional behavior as determined by the mores and customs of society. Grief comprises a stereotyped set of psychological and physiological reactions of biological origin. It is hypothesized that the adaptive function of grief is to ensure group cohesiveness in species where a social form of existence is necessary for survival. The phylogenetic and physiological evidence related to this hypothesis is reviewed, and the symptomatology of grief is examined. It is argued that discussions of grief are conspicuously rare in the psychological literature because the behavior of the bereaved is not explicable within most current models of emotion. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: grief, biological origin of psychological &; physiological reations, adaptation to social cohesiveness
Index Keywords: adaptation; adaptive behavior; anxiety; cultural anthropology; emotion; grief; guilt; hostility; human; motivation; physiology; review; Adaptation, Physiological; Adaptation, Psychological; Anxiety; Culture; Emotions; Grief; Guilt; Hostility; Human; Motivation; Physiology
Correspondence Address: Averill, J.R.; U. California, Berkeley, United States

Authors: Keutzer C.S., Lichtenstein E., Mees H.L.
Title: Modification of smoking behavior: A review
Authors with affiliations: Keutzer, C.S., U. Oregon; Lichtenstein, E.; Mees, H.L.
Abstract: Within the framework of therapy-outcome research, behavior-modification approaches to the treatment of smoking are reviewed and evaluated. Case reports, studies without control groups, and the few controlled comparisons of 2 or more treatment methods are considered separately; the behavioristic techniques are then compared against the more traditional smoking treatments (withdrawal clinics, drug treatments, group therapy). Though the lack of standardized methodology and the wide variation in S-selection procedures make strict comparison difficult, it is clear that behavior-modification techniques have not been demonstrably superior either to other treatment methods or to placebo-attention procedures. Methodological factors and conceptual issues are discussed in relation to the limited success of behavior therapies with the smoking habit. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: smoking behavior modification therapy, evaluation
Index Keywords: adolescent; adult; behavior therapy; drug therapy; electric shock; female; group therapy; human; male; review; smoking; technique; Adolescent; Adult; Behavior Therapy; Drug Therapy; Electroshock; Female; Human; Male; Methods; Psychotherapy, Group; Smoking

Title: Method, findings, and theory in studies of visual masking
Authors with affiliations: Kahneman, D., Hebrew U., Jerusalem, Israel
Abstract: Classifies the various paradigms in the study of visual masking and relates them to cases of interference among cotemporaneous stimuli. The dependent variables in masking studies are described. A distinction between criterion content and criterion level is introduced in the discussion of detection under masking and metacontrast. Various conceptions of identification of forms under masking and the contributions of masking effects to the study of psychological time are reviewed. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: research &; theory; visual masking, methodology &
Index Keywords: color; human; light; noise; pattern recognition; psychological model; review; technique; time; Color; Form Perception; Humans; Light; Methods; Models, Psychological; Noise; Time Factors
Correspondence Address: Kahneman, D.; Hebrew U., Jerusalem, Israel

Title: Explanations of geometrical illusions
Authors with affiliations: Over, R., Dalhousie U., Halifax, NS, Canada
Abstract: Demonstrates that explanations of geometrical illusions in terms of deformation of the field of retinal induction, cortical satiation, directional eyemovements, and inappropriate constancy scaling generate incorrect predictions about the viewing conditions under which perceptual error occurs. None of these accounts is likely to be satisfactory without major revision of its basic propositions. Several other theories of illusions have an uncertain status at the present time, e.g., the lateral inhibition explanation, the centration theory, and the contextual learning theory. Information is particularly needed on whether similar perceptual error occurs with visual, haptic, and tactual judgment of an illusion figure and whether illusions are products of S's learning history. The relationship between illusions and figural aftereffects requires further examination, as does the issue of whether geometrical illusions constitute a single class of perceptual effects. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: geometrical illusions, evaluation of explanations
Index Keywords: depth perception; electrostimulation; eye fixation; eye movement; human; illusion; pattern recognition; perception; physiology; retina; review; vision; visual cortex; Electric Stimulation; Eye Movements; Figural Aftereffect; Fixation, Ocular; Form Perception; Human; Illusions; Retina; Size Perception; Space Perception; Visual Cortex
Correspondence Address: Over, R.; Dalhousie U., Halifax, NS, Canada

Title: Comparison of strategies in developing scales for dominance
Authors with affiliations: Butt, D.S., U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada; Fiske, D.W.
Abstract: Classified strategies for the measurement of dominance as facet vs. trait and factorial vs. rational, yielding the 4 approaches compared in the study: rational facet, factorial facet, rational trait, factorial trait. The approaches were compared at 4 levels of evaluation: test statistics (reliability), test intercorrelations, correlations with presumably related variables, and promise of theoretical contribution. Standard and new tests of dominance and measures of other variables were given to 3 groups of Ss: male and female undergraduates, and airmen. The facet strategy was superior to the trait strategy for basic research purposes. The rational facet approach yielded more relationships with outside variables. Different purposes were required different strategies. (24 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: developing scales for dominance, rational vs. factorial facets vs. rational vs. factorial traits
Index Keywords: human; personality test; psychometry; review; social dominance; Human; Personality Assessment; Psychometrics; Social Dominance
Correspondence Address: Butt, D.S.; U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada

Title: Phobias of childhood: Etiology and treatment
Authors with affiliations: Berecz, J.M., Indiana U
Abstract: Reviews data which have appeared from 1927-1967. The stance of the reviewer is pluralistic, but, since psychoanalytic and behavioristic views have dominated the literature, a large portion of the review is devoted to these orientations. Problems relative to definitions, normative studies, etiological and treatment considerations, and follow-up studies are discussed. A distinction between etiology and treatment is maintained. Alternative viewpoints are discussed, with the implication that they are complimentary, rather than mutually exclusive. School phobias are dicussed independently of phobias in general, since the similiarities between them seem to be more terminological than etiological. (4 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: phobias in childhood, etiology &; treatment
Index Keywords: age; behavior therapy; birth order; child; cultural anthropology; family therapy; fear; human; hypnosis; phobia; psychoanalysis; review; socioeconomics; Age Factors; Behavior Therapy; Birth Order; Child; Culture; Family Therapy; Fear; Human; Hypnosis; Phobic Disorders; Psychoanalytic Therapy; Socioeconomic Factors

Authors: Locke E.A., Cartledge N., Koeppel J.
Title: Motivational effects of knowledge of results: A goal-setting phenomenon?
Authors with affiliations: Locke, E.A., U. Maryland; Cartledge, N.; Koeppel, J.
Abstract: Hypothesized that the motivational effects of knowledge of results (KR) were a function of the goals Ss set in response to such knowledge. Previous studies were classified into 4 categories according to the degree to which KR and goal setting effects were separated: (1) 1 group of studies explicitly confounded the 2 variables by assigning KR and no-KR Ss different goals; (2) other studies gave KR only in relation to standards or gave S a record of his previous performance, both of which procedures probably encouraged goal setting by KR Ss; (3) a 3rd group of studies did not involve any obvious manipulation of goals but the goals set spontaneously by the KR and no-KR Ss were not actually measured; (4) 4 studies which separated KR and goal-setting effects found significant relationships between goals and performance but no effect of KR per se. Other studies which gave multiple KR (based on independent performance parameters) found performance improvement to be restricted to that parameter on which S set a goal of improvement. (52 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: motivational effects of knowledge of results, goal setting

Title: A nonparametric comparison of two small samples with many ties
Authors with affiliations: Uleman, J.S., Michigan State U
Abstract: Describes an exact nonparametric test suitable for testing whether 1 sample is stochastically larger than another. The advantage of the test over currently available forms of the Mann-Whitney U test is that it can handle small samples with numerous ties. Comparisons with the Mann-Whitney and normal approximations to it are presented. The use of the statistic is illustrated with data drawn from current research literature. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: nonparametric comparison of 2 small samples with many shared variables

Title: Three kinds of behavioral changes
Authors with affiliations: Foa, U.G., U. Missouri
Abstract: The study of changes in a set of interrelated dependent variables reveals a fuller picture than the analysis of each variable taken separately. Using facet theory, for analyzing and comparing structures, 3 kinds of behavioral change are defined, and all of them seem to occur empirically. (1) The change in central tendency is maximal for 1 given variable and decreases systematically as one moves away from this variable toward variables gradually more remote from it in the organizational pattern. (2) The degree of relationship among the variables changes while their order remains the same. The rigidity or differentiation of the structure increases or decreases. (3) The order of the variables changes. The structure is reorganized. An example for each kind, from the areas of leadership training, personality structure, and psychotherapy, respectively, are described. (47 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: behavior changes of central tendency &; degree of relationship &; order, facet theory

Title: Properties of compound conditioned stimuli and their components
Authors with affiliations: Baker, T.W., Lawrence U
Abstract: Reviews variables which affect the strength of components in a compound CS in both classical and instrumental conditioning. Relative intensity of the components, their temporal relationship with respect to each other and to the UCS, and the extent of training and type of UCS have been found to influence the separate strengths of the components in a compound. An attempt has been made to integrate the Russian and American literature wherever possible; various types of compound CSs are compared with the results from single component CSs, dynamic stereotypes, and sensory preconditioning studies. (51 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: instrumental conditioning; strength of components in compound CS, variables in classical &

Title: The activity-drive hypothesis: Effects of activity restriction
Authors with affiliations: Lore, R.K., Douglass Coll
Abstract: Examined studies in which activity deprivation was supposedly achieved by confining rats in tiny cages for varying durations reveals little evidence that would justify the postulation of an autonomous need or drive for animals to be active. After short-term restriction (5 hr.-8 days), Ss do not show increased preferences for activity incentives nor is their activity level systematically related to confinement severity or duration. Short-term confinement appears to function as a moderate stressor which may or may not increase activity. Long-term (14-100 days) restriction of activity can best be viewed as an experiential or sensory restriction treatment that causes a relatively permanent change in Ss' emotional reaction to novel environments. (52 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: activity need after activity restriction, reaction to novel environment, time interval, rat

Title: A least squares method for fitting intercepting line segments to a set of data points
Authors with affiliations: Bogartz, R.S., U. Illinois
Abstract: Uses a search procedure to locate the least squares best location for the 2 lines to intercept. Formulas are provided for the cases when the slopes or intercepts of 1 or both lines are assumed to be known. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: fitting intercepting line segments to data, least squares

Title: Movement control in skilled motor performance
Authors with affiliations: Keele, S.W., U. Oregon
Abstract: Speed and accuracy of single movements depend on several factors, such as direction of movement, distance to the target, and accompaniment by simultaneous movements. The relation between speed, accuracy, and distance appears to be determined by the time required to process feedback and to make corrective alterations in the movement. For a repetitive series of movements, there is some evidence suggesting that control is shifted from feedback to a motor program. This view receives further support from demonstrations that the reproduction of single movements may be relevant to understanding perceptual, memory, and motor skills is mentioned. (3 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: accuracy, motor &; feedback processing; motor performance speed &

Title: Anticipation and timing in human motor performance
Authors with affiliations: Schmidt, R.A., U. Maryland
Abstract: It is indicated that anticipation and timing can be learned, and that there is substantial forgetting over retention intervals of up to 5 mo. The spatial and temporal predictability of the stimuli appear to be the most potent determiners of anticipation, but response-produced proprioceptive stimulus traces may also provide a basis for more accurate timing. Changes in the nature of the stimulus predictability produce widely different response strategies, and after considerable practice, anticipated responses become automatic, freeing S to perform other tasks simultaneously. There has been a general lack of interest concerning both intraresponse timing and the motor variables determining anticipation. (2 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: anticipation; motor performance, spatial &; temporal predictability of stimulus &

Title: Multiple regression as a general data-analytic system
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, J., New York U
Abstract: Presents techniques for using multiple regression (MR) as a general variance-accounting procedure of great flexibility, power, and fidelity to research aims in both manipulative and observational psychological research. The identity of MR and fixed-model analysis of variance/covariance (AV/ACV) is sketched. This requires an exposition of means of expressing nominal scale (qualitative) data as independent variables in MR. Attention is given to methods for handling interactions, curvilinearity, missing data, and covariates, for either uncorrelated or correlated independent variables in MR. The relative roles of AV/ACV and MR in data analysis are described, and the practical advantages of the latter are set forth. (16 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: analysis of variance &; covariance, use; multiple regression &

Title: Rejoinder to Tucker's 'Comments on "Confounding of sources of variation in factor-analytic techniques'"
Affiliations: U. Michigan, Mental Health Research Inst
Authors with affiliations: Gollob, H.F., U. Michigan, Mental Health Research Inst
Abstract: Reveals that L. R. Tucker's (see 43:2) 2nd rotated factor confounds variation due to pocket vs. wrist watch preferences and variation due to quality preferences. The factor-analytic variation (FANOVA) model does not assume that stimulus main effects represent fundamental psychological constructs. Nor does it make assumptions regarding the presence or absence of general tendencies or individual differences in the data. It describes these aspects of the data separately. Since Tucker's identities break down in most actual applications, the differences between the models are not oridinarily reduced simply to a matter of preference as to which way the mean responses are to be presented. When the intent is specifically to describe individual differences, the FANOVA analysis is more parsimonious and straightforward than analysis of original measures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: analysis of variance model/2-way, confounding sources of variation, reply to criticism

Title: Confounding of sources of variation in factor-analytic techniques
Affiliations: U. Michigan, Mental Health Research Inst
Authors with affiliations: Gollob, H.F., U. Michigan, Mental Health Research Inst
Abstract: Illustrates a statistical model which is a 2-way analysis of variance model which requires that factor-analytic techniques be used to decompose the interaction parameters. Factor-analytic techniques are commonly applied directly to matrices which contain a grand mean and/or row and/or column effects in addition to row * column interaction. Each factor obtained from such an analysis will generally account for variation due to all sources of variation present in the initial matrix. Some ways in which such confounding of sources of variation causes difficulties in making valid interpretations of factors are discussed. Special attention is given to the problem of describing individual differences in patterns of performance on a set of measurements. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: analysis of variance model/2-way, confounding sources of variation

Title: Some determinants of communication accuracy
Affiliations: U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mehrabian, A., U. California, Los Angeles, United States; Reed, H.
Abstract: Defines communication accuracy, and discusses various measures of accuracy which have been employed in the research literature. Considered as the dependent variable, accuracy in communication is conceptualized as being determined by 5 sets of independent variables: attributes of the communicator, of the addressee, of the channel, of the communication, or the referent. With these as independent variables, a series of hypotheses is suggested for predicting variations in communication accuracy. For each proposed hypothesis, available research findings are reviewed. (63 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: communication accuracy, determinants
Correspondence Address: Mehrabian, A.; U. California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Leadership functions of middle managers
Authors with affiliations: Nealey, S.M., U. Illinois; Fiedler, F.E.
Abstract: Compares the roles and functions of middle managers to those of 1st-level supervisors and higher managers. Theory, training practices, and empirical studies disagree on the part the middle manager plays in large organizations. Recent evidence suggests that there are important differences in the functions of 1st- and 2nd-level managers and that the effect of the 2nd- or 3rd-level manager on morale and performance has been underrated. The most successful supervisor at the 1st level may not be highly successful at the 2nd level of management. The literature suggests a shift in research emphasis from the group to the organization as the unit of analysis, and from the study of managerial personality to the study of managerial functions as a means of identifying at each organizational level the combination of leadership and situational factors conducive to organizational performance. (3 p. ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: managers/middle, leadership functions &; role in organizational structure
Index Keywords: achievement; administrative personnel; attitude; education; human; leadership; organization; organization and management; review; role playing; Achievement; Administrative Personnel; Attitude; Humans; Leadership; Organization and Administration; Organizations; Role

Title: Hippocampus and internal inhibition
Authors with affiliations: Kimble, D.P., U. Oregon
Abstract: Proposes that the mammalian hippocampus constitutes part of the neural machinery necessary for the generation of a brain process which is functionally equivalent to Pavlovian internal inhibition. Relevant neuroanatomical and electrophysiological data are presented in support of this proposal. The major behavioral effects of hippocampal lesions in situations in which internal inhibition is presumed to occur are discussed. These situations include habituation to novelty, discrimination reversal, overtraining, extinction, and spontaneous alternation. (69 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: electrophysiology, Pavlovian internal inhibition; hippocampal neuroanatomy &
Index Keywords: animal; animal behavior; arousal; electrophysiology; hippocampus; histology; instrumental conditioning; learning; memory; physiology; rat; reaction time; reinforcement; review; Animals; Arousal; Behavior, Animal; Conditioning, Operant; Electrophysiology; Extinction, Psychological; Hippocampus; Memory; Practice (Psychology); Rats; Reaction Time

Authors: Goldstein M.J., Held J.M., Cromwell R.L.
Title: Premorbid adjustment and paranoid-nonparanoid status in schizophrenia
Affiliations: U. California, Los Angeles, United States
Authors with affiliations: Goldstein, M.J., U. California, Los Angeles, United States; Held, J.M.; Cromwell, R.L.
Abstract: Using 98 schizophrenics, good premorbids were found to be evenly distributed regarding paranoid vs. nonparanoid symptomatology. Poor premorbids were predominantly nonparanoid and rarely paranoid. However, paranoids were predominantly good premorbids, whereas nonparanoids were distributed between good and poor premorbids. (15 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: premorbid adjustment, paranoid vs. nonparanoid schizophrenics

Correspondence Address: Goldstein, M.J.; U. California, Los Angeles, United States

Title: Search for "closure" in a visually perceived pattern
Authors with affiliations: Holmes, D.S., U. Texas
Abstract: From the Gestalt concept of closure, it has been predicted that the memory trace for a gapped circle pattern will go through a progressive change such that the gap will be recalled as having been smaller. The research on this, the most basic prediction from the concept of closure, is reviewed and evaluated. Rather than supporting the prediction of closure, results of most studies indicated that the predominant change in the memory trace was in the direction of opening the gap. (45 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: closure of gapped circle pattern
Index Keywords: cultural anthropology; human; learning; memory; personality; review; technique; vision; Culture; Humans; Memory; Methods; Perceptual Closure; Personality; Set (Psychology); Visual Perception

Title: Comments on "Confounding of sources of variation in factor-analytic techniques"
Authors with affiliations: Tucker, L.R., U. Illinois
Abstract: Relations between H. F. Gollob's (see 43:2) factor-analytic variation (FANOVA) analysis and an Eckart-Young resolution of original data are compared and illustrated with a fictitious body of data. When transformations of factor matrices (rotation of axes) are included in the analysis, a number of points of equivalence occur between the 2 analyses. A major point of difference concerns representation of mean responses. In the FANOVA model, mean responses to stimuli are taken as characteristics of the stimuli; in the Eckart-Young resolution of original data, the mean responses are described in terms of the centroid of factor scores. A preference is stated for later representation as an aspect of description of the population of a person. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: analysis of variance model/2-way, confounding sources of variation, criticism

Title: On the interpretation of factor analysis
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, J.S., U. Pennsylvania, Wharton School; Soelberg, P.
Abstract: Illustrates the importance of the researcher's interpretation of factor analysis. Results from this example appear to be meaningful and easily interpreted. The example omits any measure of reliability or validity. If a measure of reliability had been included, it would have indicated the worthlessness of the results. A survey of 46 recent papers supports the claim that the example is typical, as 2/3 of the papers provide no measure of reliability. Some papers did not even provide sufficient information to allow for replication. To improve the current situation some measure of factor reliability should accompany applied studies which utilize factor analysis. 3 operational approaches are suggested for obtaining measures of factor reliability; use of split samples, Monte Carlo simulation, and a priori models. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: factor analysis use by researchers, need for measure of reliability &; validity
Correspondence Address: Armstrong, J.S.; U. Pennsylvania, Wharton School

Title: An example of Bayesian hypothesis testing: The perception of rotary motion in depth
Authors with affiliations: Pitz, G.F., Southern Illinois U
Abstract: Illustrates the Bayesian method of employing likelihood ratios in an analysis of an experiment reported by W. A. Hershberger (see 41:7), supposedly disconfirming a theory proposed by R. H. Day and R. P. Power (see 39:4). The original experiment produced results significant at the .02 level when using a 1-tailed test. It is shown that, by interpreting these results as evidence against the null hypothesis, one is making strong assumptions that should be recognized. The Bayesian analysis suggests that the null hypothesis is not discredited nearly as much as is suggested by the classical significance level. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: Bayesian hypothesis testing, experimental illustration

Title: Manifest dichotomy analysis
Authors with affiliations: Du Mas, F.M., Augusta Coll
Abstract: Manifest dichotomy analysis (MDA) is a modification of manifest structure analysis (MSA). MDA is designed to predict a qualitative criterion rather than a quantitative one. Conceptual and perceptual search models are rationalized which permit the extraction of an ordered structure of predictor items from a mixed and unordered item sample. Application of MDA to only Exercise 1, Form A, of the Terman and Miles masculinity-femininity test resulted in the empirical extraction of a 40-item test and scoring key. The MDA test exhibited great practical superiority and approximately equal reliability and validity in comparison with the 910-item combined full-length forms of the Terman and Miles test. (27 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: manifest dichotomy analysis, prediction of qualitative criterion

Title: Weighted kappa: Nominal scale agreement provision for scaled disagreement or partial credit
Authors with affiliations: Cohen, J., New York U
Abstract: A previously described coefficient of agreement for nominal scales, kappa, treats all disagreements equally. A generalization to weighted kappa (Kw) is presented. The Kw provides for the incorpation of ratio-scaled degrees of disagreement (or agreement) to each of the cells of the k * k table of joint nominal scale assignments such that disagreements of varying gravity (or agreements of varying degree) are weighted accordingly. Although providing for partial credit, Kw is fully chance corrected. Its sampling characteristics and procedures for hypothesis testing and setting confidence limits are given. Under certain conditions, Kw equals product-moment r. The use of unequal weights for symmetrical cells makes Kw suitable as a measure of validity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: weighted kappa coefficient for nominal scales, provision for scaled disagreement
Index Keywords: article; human; mental disease; methodology; psychometry; sample size; statistical model; Humans; Likelihood Functions; Mental Disorders; Models, Statistical; Psychometrics; Research Design; Sample Size

Title: In defense of Arnold's theory of emotion
Affiliations: Loyola U., Chicago, Ill, United States
Authors with affiliations: Arnold, M.B., Loyola U., Chicago, Ill, United States
Abstract: Criticizes M. L. Goldstein's (see 42:4) review of Arnold's theory of emotion because he disregards her major work (1960) and misinterprets her 1950 version. His assumption that a theory must be couched in objectivist terms to be testable is untenable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: Arnold's theory of emotion, defense
Index Keywords: adaptation; article; emotion; human; psychological theory; Adaptation, Physiological; Emotions; Human; Psychological Theory
Correspondence Address: Arnold, M.B.; Loyola U., Chicago, Ill, United States

Title: Comparative validities of forced-choice and single-stimulus tests
Authors with affiliations: Scott, W.A., U. Colorado
Abstract: The generalization that forced-choice personality inventories are more valid than single-stimulus forms of the same tests is not supported by critical consideration of relevant evidence. Only 1 study that claimed superior validity of the forced-choice format appeared to have used identical items in the 2 forms. Other studies either did not employ single-stimulus forms for comparison, or did not hold item content constant between the 2 forms, or else yielded nonconfirming results. The most tenable conclusion at present is that test validity does not depend on this characteristic of item format under the circumstances in which these self-report inventories are typically administered. This was also the conclusion from the writer's investigation of 3 tests: the Edwards Personal Preference Schedule, the Allport-Vernon-Lindzey Study of Values, and Scott's value scales. (45 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: comparative validities of forced-choice &; single-stimulus tests, personality inventories
Index Keywords: personality test; psychometry; review; social desirability; technique; Methods; Personality Inventory; Psychometrics; Social Desirability

Title: Verbal transformation effect and auditory perceptual mechanisms
Authors with affiliations: Warren, R.M., U. Wisconsin, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: Continued listening to recorded repetitions of a single word or phrase induces illusory changes. These "verbal transformations" (VT's) range from a word that rhymes with the actual stimulus to extreme phonetic distortions. The VT effect has revealed semantic and phonetic aspects of verbal organizational processes. It is suggested that the strategies employed for the perception of connected discourse change in a regular manner throughout the normal life span. Some aspects of VT's appear related to other perceptual phenomena including aphasia and both auditory and visual illusions induced by unchanging patterns of sensory input. (35 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: auditory perceptual mechanisms &; verbal transformation effect
Index Keywords: adult; aged; article; hearing; human; linguistics; Adult; Aged; Auditory Perception; Human; Middle Age; Psycholinguistics
Correspondence Address: Warren, R.M.; U. Wisconsin, Milwaukee, United States

Title: Binomial variability in short-term memory
Authors with affiliations: Murdock Jr., B.B., U. Toronto, Ont., Canada; Ogilvie, J.C.
Abstract: Experiments in short-term memory usually collect binary data, e.g., an item is either correctly recalled or not. If the probability of recall is constant for Ss and/or items under a given condition, the proportion based on n observations can be transformed to angles by the arcsin transformation and will have variance 1/n. Violations of the assumptions are discussed and different strategies for pooling are assessed by conventional analysis of variance. Illustrative experiments with distractor and probe techniques, paired-associates and serial presentation, and single-trial free recall are briefly presented. The correspondence between observed and expected results seems good; apparently considerable latitude is possible in pooling Ss or items in data analyses of experiments in short-term memory. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: binomial variability in short-term memory experiments
Index Keywords: analysis of variance; article; psychometry; short term memory; Analysis of Variance; Memory, Short-Term; Psychometrics
Correspondence Address: Murdock Jr., B.B.; U. Toronto, Ont., Canada

Title: Warning and persuasion
Authors with affiliations: Papageorgis, D., U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada
Abstract: Reviewed studies dealing with the effects on audience opinions of (1) advance information about the topics and the direction of argument of forthcoming communications (warning), and (2) instructions that describe the experiment as a study of opinion change (persuasion context). Conclusions include: (1) warning and persuasion context are not separate manipulations; (2) their effects on postcommunication opinion change are not clear; and (3) warning and persuasion context probably cause precommunication opinion change. It is suggested that neither warning nor persuasion context, by themselves, are crucial variables in postcommunication opinion change. In some instances persuasion may begin prior to actual exposure to persuasive communications. (32 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: persuasion effects on audience opinions, review of research; warning &
Index Keywords: article; human; learning; persuasive communication; public opinion; Human; Persuasive Communication; Public Opinion; Set (Psychology)
Correspondence Address: Papageorgis, D.; U. British Columbia, Vancouver, Canada

Title: Magnitude of experimental effect and a table for its rapid estimation
Authors with affiliations: Friedman, H., Coll. of William and Mary
Abstract: Sample size and probability values must be involved in the interpretation of experimental data. A correlation between group membership and the dependent variable explicitly describes the effectiveness of the independent variable. A table is provided which gives values of this measure directly from the sample size and t, z, F, or X2 values. Equivalents of this measure are provided both in terms of the difference between means and a measure of misclassification. The table is suitable as a power table and for dealing with several problems of experimental procedure and tactics. Decisions concerning acceptance of null or alternative hypotheses may be aided by the use of this measure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: estimation table for magnitude of experimental effect
Correspondence Address: Friedman, H.; Coll. of William and Mary

Title: COMPARATIVE PSYCHOLOGICAL STUDIES OF NEGROES AND WHITES IN THE UNITED STATES: 1959-1965
Authors with affiliations: DREGER, R.M., LOUISIANA STATE U; MILLER, K.S.
Abstract: TOPICS OF THE REVIEW INCLUDE: THE PHYSICAL SUBSTRATA OF PSYCHOLOGICAL AND PSYCHOSOCIAL FUNCTIONS, PHYSICAL AND MOTOR DEVELOPMENT, PSYCHOPHYSICAL FUNCTIONS, INTELLECTUAL FUNCTIONS, EDUCATIONAL AND OCCUPATIONAL ATTAINMENT AND ASPIRATIONS, TEMPERAMENT, SOCIAL PERCEPTIONS AND ATTITUDES, MENTAL ILLNESS, CRIME AND DELINQUENCY, AND FAMILY ORGANIZATION. RESEARCH RESULTS FROM THIS PERIOD GENERALLY CONFIRM THE SUMMARY STATEMENTS MADE IN A SIMILAR REVIEW BY R. M. DREGER AND K. S. MILLER (SEE 35:4). ALTHOUGH THE LITERATURE REFLECTS SOME INCREASE IN SOPHISTICATION OF DESIGN OF COMPARATIVE STUDIES, MANY INADEQUACIES CONTINUE TO EXIST. MEANINGFUL COMPARATIVE STUDIES MIGHT REQUIRE MORE COMPLEX EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURES AND DESIGNS INVOLVING A NUMBER OF INTERACTIONS. (9 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: Verbal behavior in schizophrenia: A review of recent studies
Affiliations: Massachusetts Mental Health Center, Boston, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pavy, D., Massachusetts Mental Health Center, Boston, MA, United States
Abstract: journal abstract: Research in 4 areas of schizophrenic speech is reviewed: word associations, ambiguity and metaphor, information content and communicability of speech, contextual constraints and speech perception. It is found that most of the work involves the relation of behavioral deficits to speech production and perception. The works are considered from the viewpoint of contemporary psycholinguistics, and their approaches to language are noted and criticized. Suggestions for future research are made. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ambiguity; contextual constraints; information content; metaphor; schizophrenia; speech; speech communicability; speech perception; verbal behavior; word associations

Title: STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE IN PSYCHOLOGICAL RESEARCH
Authors with affiliations: LYKKEN, D.T., U. MINNESOTA
Abstract: MOST THEORIES IN THE AREAS OF PERSONALITY, CLINICAL, AND SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY PREDICT ONLY THE DIRECTION OF A CORRELATION, GROUP DIFFERENCE, OR TREATMENT EFFECT. SINCE THE NULL HYPOTHESIS IS NEVER STRICTLY TRUE, SUCH PREDICTIONS HAVE ABOUT A 50-50 CHANCE OF BEING CONFIRMED BY EXPERIMENT WHEN THE THEORY IN QUESTION IS FALSE, SINCE THE STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE OF THE RESULT IS A FUNCTION OF THE SAMPLE SIZE. CONFIRMATION OF 1 DIRECTIONAL PREDICTION GENERALLY BUILDS LITTLE CONFIDENCE IN THE THEORY BEING TESTED. MOST THEORIES SHOULD BE TESTED BY MULTIPLE CORROBORATION AND MOST EMPIRICAL GENERALIZATIONS BY CONSTRUCTIVE REPLICATION. STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE, PERHAPS THE LEAST IMPORTANT ATTRIBUTE OF A GOOD EXPERIMENT, IS NEVER A SUFFICIENT CONDITION FOR CLAIMING THAT (1) A THEORY HAS BEEN USEFULLY CORROBORATED, (2) A MEANINGFUL EMPIRICAL FACT HAS BEEN ESTABLISHED, OR (3) AN EXPERIMENTAL REPORT OUGHT TO BE PUBLISHED. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: STATISTICAL SIGNIFICANCE IN PSYCHOLOGICAL RESEARCH
Index Keywords: article; psychology; Psychology; Statistics

Title: SOME REASONS FOR THE APPARENT INCONSISTENCY OF PERSONALITY
Authors with affiliations: BLOCK, J., U. CALIFORNIA, BERKELEY
Abstract: THE EMPIRICAL LITERATURE ON CONSISTENCY OF PERSONALITY IS REPLETE WITH INSTANCES OF THE ABSENCE OF "EXPECTED" RELATIONSHIPS. CONCEPTUAL REASONS ARE LISTED THAT MAY ACCOUNT FOR THESE APPARENT INCONSISTENCIES: (1) THE MIXING OF BEHAVIORS OF DIFFERENT LEVELS OF SALIENCE, (2) THE FAILURE TO RECOGNIZE THE EFFECT OF ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS, (3) THE COMPARISON OF BEHAVIORS MEDIATED BY DIFFERENT UNDERLYING VARIABLES, AND (4) THE FAILURE TO SPECIFY OR TO RECOGNIZE THE BOUNDS WITHIN WHICH THE POSITED RELATIONSHIP MAY BE EXPECTED TO EXIST. CLEARER AND CLOSER CONCEPTUALIZATION WITH REGARD TO THESE ISSUES CAN SET THE STAGE FOR IMPROVED EMPIRICAL DEMONSTRATIONS OF PERSONALITY CONSISTENCY. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved).
Author Keywords: CONSISTENCY VS. INCONSISTENCY IN PERSONALITY
Index Keywords: article; ego; human; personality; Ego; Human; Personality

Title: FURTHER COMMENTS ON "IS THE FIGURAL AFTEREFFECT AN AFTEREFFECT?"
Authors with affiliations: IMMERGLUCK, L., SAN FRANCISCO STATE COLL
Abstract: GANZ' CONTENTION THAT FIGURAL AFTEREFFECT PHENOMENA AND OPTICAL ILLUSION RESPONSES ARE BASED ON IDENTICAL UNDERLYING PROCESSES, THE ONLY DIFFERENCE BEING THE TEMPORAL ORDER OF STIMULUS PRESENTATION, IS NOT SUPPORTED BY RECENT DATA WHICH REVEAL A NEGATIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN AFTEREFFECT STRENGTH AND OPTICAL ILLUSION RESPONSES. THOSE SS WHO EXHIBIT POTENT AFTEREFFECTS ARE ABLE TO COUNTERACT OPTICAL ILLUSIONS; SS WHO SHOW WEAK AFTEREFFECTS RESPOND STRONGLY TO ILLUSIONS. THE DATA SHOW FURTHER THAT BOTH AFTEREFFECTS AND OPTICAL ILLUSION RESPONSES ARE RELATED TO PERCEPTUAL MEASURES OF "FIELD DEPENDENCE," BUT IN OPPOSING DIRECTIONS: FIELD INDEPENDENT SS EXHIBIT POTENT AFTEREFFECTS BUT COUNTERACT VISUAL ILLUSIONS, WHILE FIELD DEPENDENT SS SHOW WEAK AFTEREFFECTS AND STRONG ILLUSION RESPONSES. IT IS CONCLUDED THAT THE PROCESSES GENERATING AFTEREFFECTS DIFFER FROM THOSE WHICH CREATE OPTICAL ILLUSION RESPONSES. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: FIGURAL AFTEREFFECT PHENOMENA &; OPTICAL ILLUSION RESPONSES, UNDERLYING PROCESSES
Index Keywords: article; human; vision; Figural Aftereffect; Human

Title: A CONTROL GROUP DESIGN FOR EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES OF DEVELOPMENTAL PROCESSES
Authors with affiliations: SOLOMON, R.L., U. PENNSYLVANIA; LESSAC, M.S.
Abstract: DESCRIBES THE APPLICATION OF A 4-GROUP EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN TO STUDIES OF BEHAVIOR DEVELOPMENT. THE DESIGN MAKES POSSIBLE A WIDE VARIETY OF INTERPRETATIONS ABOUT DEVELOPMENTAL PROCESSES. SUCH INTERPRETATIONS CANNOT SAFELY BE MADE WITH THE USUAL 2-GROUP DESIGN, WHICH CAN OFTEN PRODUCE MISLEADING RESULTS. SOME EXAMPLES ARE GIVEN OF THE USE OF THE 4-GROUP DESIGN IN ISOLATION AND ENRICHMENT EXPERIMENTS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: EXPERIMENTAL STUDIES OF DEVELOPMENTAL PROCESSES, CONTROL GROUP DESIGN

Title: A GENERAL CANONICAL CORRELATION INDEX
Authors with affiliations: STEWART, D., U. PITTSBURGH; LOVE, W.
Abstract: BECAUSE A CANONICAL CORRELATION IS THE CORRELATION BETWEEN 2 LINEAR COMPOSITES, IT PRESENTS SOME INTERPRETIVE PROBLEMS. NO MEASURE OF THE REDUNDANCY IN 1 SET OF VARIABLES, GIVEN ANOTHER SET OF VARIABLES, HAS BEEN AVAILABLE. A NONSYMMETRIC INDEX OF REDUNDANCY IS PROPOSED WHICH REPRESENTS THE AMOUNT OF PREDICTED VARIANCE IN A SET OF VARIABLES. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CANONICAL CORRELATION INDEX
Index Keywords: article; psychometry; Psychometrics

Title: ASSOCIATION RULES IN THE PREDICTION OF RECALL FROM FREE-ASSOCIATION MATRICES
Authors with affiliations: BILODEAU, E.A., TULANE U; HOWELL, D.C.
Abstract: EXAMINES THE METHODOLOGICAL FEATURES OF THE RELATION BETWEEN WORD-ASSOCIATION BEHAVIOR AND MEMORY FOR WORDS. THE ALGEBRA AND STRUCTURE OF POTENTIAL ASSOCIATIVE VARIABLES WERE ELABORATED AND EVALUATED USING RETENTION PHENOMENA IN THE RECALL OF COMMON WORDS. WORD-ASSOCIATION PROBABILITIES IN THE NETWORKS OF RELATED HIERARCHIES FROM 1000 SS WERE SEARCHED FOR STRENGTH OF ASSOCIATION, ASSOCIATIVE COMPETITORS, AND MEDIATORS, AND NUMBER OF ASSOCIATIVE GATEWAYS. THESE MEASURES WERE USED AS PREDICTORS OF RETENTION DATA FROM 700 OTHER SS WHERE PROBABILITY OF RETRIEVAL BY ITEM SERVED AS THE CRITERION. SEVERAL LIVELY ASSOCIATIVE PREDICTORS WERE IDENTIFIED. SPECIFICATION OF STRUCTURES WITHIN AND BETWEEN ASSOCIATIVE HIERARCHIES RELATES TO UNDERSTANDING THE RESPONSES OF INDIVIDUALS IN STIMULATED RECALL AND IN FREE ASSOCIATION ITSELF. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: ASSOCIATION RULES; PREDICTION OF RECALL FROM FREE-ASSOCIATION MATRICES &

Title: SOME PROFILE METHODS USEFUL WITH SINGULAR COVARIANCE MATRICES
Authors with affiliations: MARKS, E., GEORGIA INST. OF TECHNOLOGY
Abstract: PRESENTS 2 METHODS FOR MAKING COMPARISONS AMONG K GROUPS INVOLVING THE SHAPE OF THE GROUP MEAN VECTORS, WHEN THE NUMBER OF OBSERVATIONS IS LESS THAN THE NUMBER OF VARIABLES. THE COVARIANCE MATRIX OF THE P VARIABLES IS SINGULAR. THE 1ST METHOD INVOLVES A STEPWISE MULTIVARIATE ANALYSIS OF VARIANCE OF THE (N-1) PRINCIPAL COMPONENTS OF THE P VARIABLES. THE 2ND METHOD IS A 2 SAMPLE RANDOMIZATION TEST INVOLVING THE PERMUTATION OF THE N OBSERVATIONS AND THE EVALUATION OF THE CONDITIONAL PROBABILITIES OF THE SUMS OF CERTAIN RANK DIFFERENCES. (19 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: SINGULAR COVARIANCE MATRICES, PROFILE METHODS

Title: SOME UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES OF RIGOROUS RESEARCH
Authors with affiliations: ARGYRIS, C., YALE U
Abstract: THE PROPER USE OF RIGOROUS RESEARCH DESIGNS IN EXPERIMENTAL OR FIELD SETTINGS TENDS TO PLACE SS VIS-A-VIS THE RESEARCHER AND RESEARCH ASSISTANTS VIS-A-VIS THE SENIOR INVESTIGATOR IN SITUATIONS THAT ARE SIMILAR TO THOSE THAT ORGANIZATIONS CREATE FOR LOWER LEVEL EMPLOYEES. BY DRAWING ON ORGANIZATIONAL THEORY, PREDICTIONS OF S REACTIONS SUCH AS DEPENDENCY UPON THE RESEARCHER, OVERT AND COVERT WITHDRAWAL, AGGRESSION TOWARD THE RESEARCHER, AND EVENTUAL BANDING TOGETHER BY SS TO PROTECT THEIR INTERESTS ARE DERIVED AND ILLUSTRATED. (24 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: RIGOROUS RESEARCH DESIGNS &; UNINTENDED CONSEQUENCES

Title: PSYCHOPHYSIOLOGICAL CORRELATES OF CONDITIONED RESPONSE FORMATION
Authors with affiliations: GERMANA, J., VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST
Abstract: REVIEWS STUDIES EMPLOYING CENTRAL AND PERIPHERAL MEASURES OF ACTIVATIONAL RESPONSE DURING CONDITIONING THAT HAVE PROVIDED CONSIDERABLE REPLICATION ACROSS SS AND EXPERIMENTAL TASKS FOR AN "ACTIVATIONAL PEAKING" (AP) EFFECT. THE EFFECT CONSISTS OF THE FOLLOWING SEQUENCE OF EVENTS: AS A STIMULUS TAKES ON THE PROPERTIES OF A CS, I.E., DURING THE INITIAL STAGES OF LEARNING, ACTIVATIONAL RESPONSES SYSTEMATICALLY INCREASE IN MAGNITUDE; FURTHER ELABORATION OF THE CR THEN RESULTS IN SUCCESSIVE ACTIVATIONAL DECREMENTS. SOME METHODOLOGICAL CONSIDERATIONS IN THE PRODUCTION OF LEARNING AP ARE CONSIDERED AS WELL AS SOME INTERPRETIVE PROBLEMS. (45 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: TECHNIQUES FOR ESTIMATING THE SOURCE AND DIRECTION OF CAUSAL INFLUENCE IN PANEL DATA
Authors with affiliations: YEE, A.H., U. WISCONSIN; GAGE, N.L.
Abstract: DESCRIBES TECHNIQUES FOR ESTIMATING THE SOURCE AND DIRECTION OF CAUSAL INFLUENCE IN PANEL DATA AND APPLIES THEM TO ILLUSTRATIVE DATA ON TEACHERS' AND PUPILS' INTERPERSONAL ATTITUDES. THE TECHNIQUES ARE LAZARSFELD'S 16-FOLD TABLE, CAMPBELL'S CROSS-LAGGED PANEL CORRELATION, AND THE AUTHORS' FREQUENCY-OF-SHIFT-ACROSS-MEDIAN AND FREQUENCY-OF-CHANGE-IN-PRODUCT-MOMENT. THE LATTER METHOD SEEMS PREFERABLE BECAUSE IT PERMITS TREATMENT OF CONTINUOUS DATA, ANALYSIS OF ALL CASES, AND A NECESSARY DISTINCTION BETWEEN THE SOURCE AND DIRECTION OF CAUSAL INFLUENCE. (30 REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
Author Keywords: CAUSAL INFLUENCE IN PANEL DATA, ESTIMATING TECHNIQUES
Index Keywords: attitude; human; human relation; review; social psychology; student; teaching; technique; Attitude; Humans; Interpersonal Relations; Methods; Psychology, Social; Students; Teaching

Title: EFFECTIVENESS OF T-GROUP EXPERIENCES IN MANAGERIAL TRAINING AND DEVELOPMENT
Authors with affiliations: CAMPBELL, J.P., U. MINNESOTA; DUNNETTE, M.D.
Abstract: REVIEWS RESEARCH RELATING T-GROUP EXPERIENCES TO HUMAN BEHAVIOR IN ORGANIZATIONS. ATTENTION IS ALSO DEVOTED TO SUMMARIZING THE STATED OBJECTIVES OF THE METHOD AND ITS TECHNOLOGICAL ELEMENTS. SPECULATIONS ARE MADE ABOUT THE NATURE AND VIABILITY OF IMPLICIT ASSUMPTIONS UNDERLYING T-GROUP TRAINING. EXAMINATION OF THE RESEARCH LITERATURE LEADS TO THE CONCLUSION THAT WHILE T-GROUP TRAINING SEEMS TO PRODUCE OBSERVABLE CHANGES IN BEHAVIOR, THE UTILITY OF THESE CHANGES FOR THE PERFORMANCE OF INDIVIDUALS IN THEIR ORGANIZATIONAL ROLES REMAINS TO BE DEMONSTRATED. IT IS ALSO EVIDENT THAT MORE RESEARCH HAS BEEN DEVOTED TO T-GROUP TRAINING THAN TO ANY OTHER SINGLE MANAGEMENT-DEVELOPMENT TECHNIQUE; HOWEVER, THE PROBLEMS OF OBSERVATION AND MEASUREMENT ARE CONSIDERABLY MORE DIFFICULT IN T-GROUP RESEARCH. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.

Title: HUMAN FIGURE DRAWINGS: THEIR UTILITY IN THE CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGIST'S ARMAMENTARIUM FOR PERSONALITY ASSESSMENT
Authors with affiliations: ROBACK, H.B., YORK U., ONTARIO, Canada
Abstract: REVIEWS 18 YEARS (1949-1967) OF RESEARCH FINDINGS ON THE DRAW-A-PERSON TEST AND DISCUSSES THE VALUE OF FIGURE DRAWINGS IN THE CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGIST'S ARMAMENTARIUM. THE STUDIES CITED GENERALLY FAILED TO SUPPORT MACHOVER'S HYPOTHESES, BUT REVEALED A PAUCITY OF WELL-DESIGNED INVESTIGATIONS INDICATING THAT THIS TEST SHOULD BE REMOVED FROM THE CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGIST'S TEST BATTERY. IT IS EMPHASIZED THAT THERE IS A GREAT NEED FOR STANDARDIZED AND VALIDATED SCALES FOR ESTIMATING PERSONALITY ADJUSTMENT FROM FIGURE DRAWINGS. (2 P. REF.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1968 American Psychological Association.
